content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												This was such an interesting game, it truly was. For those who enjoy games that are based more on plot than FPS or anything else, this is the game for you. The beginning of season 1 to the end of season 2 had me smiling, crying and even yelling. This is a very excellent game and I would reccommend to everyone and anyone. It's a story of a young girl who is lost in a world filled with chaos and the undead. Clementine has to survive throughout this with the people she's met, taking her on a wild journey to escape from the dead. It was a truly heartbreaking and emotional game, but I would put my funding into a season 3. Keep it up Telltale! :) "To the loved ones that we've lost along the way, and to the hope that we see them again, one day." - LukeEdit as of 1/5/17: I am happy to say that Telltale has come up with a season 3! I thought I was going to be disappointed by not being able to play Clem a lot, but I was wrong. Season 3 had me doubting myself. Thank you Telltale for the amazing series and I hope it continues further past season 3, even if it is new. Your games are amazing! <3

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												After how good Season 1 was, Season 2 had pretty big shoes to fill that it probably never could fill in the first place. But it's not too far off either. Season 2 follows up from Season 1 (woohoo for imported saves), though sadly 400 days seems like it was a waste of time after all. I want to say there is less action this time around, but that wouldn't really be true. Rather its that the change from playing as Lee Everett to Clementine that results in less fights for the player to get involved in directly, which is kinda neat in its own way. 10 year old girls aren't expected to do as much melee stuff as a 37 year old man would, though you still do some of that here.There's also less adventure game style puzzles to do... alot less. Most of the gameplay here is dialogue choices and relatively brief action sequences, which almost puts this game into visual novel territory. It's a shame because there are far fewer opportunities for wandering around just chatting or interacting with the environment, which weakens the character development a bit for the new faces that don't get much time. It means that Season 2's episodes are generally shorter, but it also means that you spend less time wandering about and more time following the plot. A plot that is still quite good, though perhaps not as likely to bring people to tears as some of the bigger moments of Season 1 did. Nothing in Season 2 got that to happen for me, though the finale came close as you find yourself making rough choices that can give you very different endings (unlike Season 1, which ended the same way no matter what).I'd say the high points of the season are found in Episodes 2 and 5 (which are also the longest episodes), with the other episodes mainly serving as build-up towards those bigger moments. I'm not sure where this series will go from here, but it seems very likely that we will see a Season 3. Whether that is with who ultimately makes it out of Season 2 or not (which has to consolidate the varied endings for this season), or if it is an entirely new cast, is uncertain. Until we find out... enjoy this one. It's pretty good. :)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Another rollercoaster ride of emotions, this Season 2 imho is not epic and heart moving like the previous one, but the idea of seeing how Clementine's growing up and shaping her character after all that happenend to her in S1 was a perfect choice from Telltale. The first episodes slowly introduce the new characters and relationships between them, then from the end of Episode 3, through EP4 and 5, everything speeds up, taking you to the final escalation and to five different possible endings. Choices you make during S2 are not determinant until the last minutes of EP5, and that's a shame because this gives you too little REAL decisional power, but it was nice to have a so hectic and variable ending. Now I'm curious to see what will happen in Season 3 and if the main character will change again.There are also some plot holes here and there, things happen without explanations, some questions are left there without a real answer. I also found some new charaters to be really interesting and well built, others instead barely newsworthy. And well, sometimes Clementine is appointed with decisions and tasks too heavy for a small girl like her, not realistic and a bit forced by script and gameplay reasons, but fun nonetheless!I liked Season 2, I recommend it to everyone who loved Season 1, however you need to know and like Telltale narrative and graphical style, so if you never played TWD or The Wolf Among Us, start from there before buying this one.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												The sequel is just as good if not better than Season 1.  The story told in this season is filled with heart wrenching choices that affect the rest of the story.  Graphics look similar to Season 1 and still look good, except that I felt the animation and graphics were smoother and less glitchy than Season 1.  You have a lot more action to deal with in this game than its predecessor and it is well implemented.  None of the puzzles are difficult, most there to pace the game properly and allow you to speak with individuals in your group to get more background story on them.  As typical in the series, the choices you make can be tough and emotional and what's even better is that the choices from Season 1 come back to affect the game here in Season 2.I highly recommend playing Season 1 before Season 2 simply because it's nice to see your choices making a difference in the way you interact with other characters in this game.  It's not necessary, but it will help, especially since they do often speak about characters, both minor and major characters, from the first game.Another great addition to the Telltale Games library.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												If you are reading this review, I am assuming that you've already played the first season of this game. Gameplay wise, there's not much difference compared to the previous game. As for the story, it seems to be focused more on survival and just making it "from one day to another", but there's still place for emotions. Just not as much of them as the first game had. I think I've enjoyed season one a bit more, but if you've liked the previous season I don't see a reason why wouldn't you like season 2. The only flaw is, again, the fact that our choices don't affect the big picture most of the times. Oh, and the graphics improved some. I'm not a guy who cares much for grahpics, but they've done a great job with shading. As for the fact that we're playing as a child now... This didn't affect my experience, really. As in, gameplay-wise it's all the same... Story wise, of course people treat Clementine different than they've treated Lee. And Clem being smaller and all, has a bigger problem killing zombies than Lee did. But that's all.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												The gameplay is more refined in Season 2, focusing on the game's strengths while reducing the classic point and click sections, which often broke the flow in Season 1, to a very healthy minimum. It is indeed a stellar interactive experience from beginning to end.The story, however, suffered in Season 2 - the absence of the dynamic between Lee and Clementine hurts the game and similar bonds aren't formed. New characters the player is supposed to care for rarely live longer than half an episode.The game is trying to show the impact this post apocalyptic world has on Clementine but is ultimately leaving the player equally jaded and emotionally drained. It's hard to tell if that makes the game successful or not ...That said, despite its flaws, it still has some of the best storytelling in any modern game and should be considered a classic of the genre much like season 1.

												Calm the fukc down, no spoilers. I get your pain.Robert Kirkman is a man of entertainment and many talents. And he's a kinda a guy you would give Oscar to or slap so hard.Well, judging by franchise decisions for "The Walking Dead", Kirkman's should be greatly awarded AND punched in the face even harder. The guy, alongside his collagues gave us AWESOME COMICS, pretty solid novels, some great games and probably the ♥♥♥♥♥iest zombie show that ever stumbled on our screens. Yes, I am talking about AMC's The Walking Dead and I ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ HATE IT. In case you need to ask why, you either don't know what "The Walking Dead" is all about, or you're ignorant and you should be slapped, too.Now, let's get back to episodic adventure game "The Walking Dead" that's published by Telltale Games. In 2012 we got Season One, consisting of five episodes, and now we're stuck in the middle of Season 2, with Episode 4 on the way, biting our nails and hailing a great villain Bill Carver voiced by one and only Michael Madsen.In case you haven't tried The Walking Dead before, it's an episodic not-really-adventure-but-more-of-a-interactive-novel game that puts you in position of choosing dialogues and actions which will directly influence the story - yes, it's a game that requires less reflexes than any other zombie game. Without need to dissect the Season 1 here, I'll skip to Season 2 right away.Season 2 leans even more toward storytelling mode. It's a story driven season that will require even less actions, movements, but the decisions shall be huge and will leave you wanting more. As for the characters, Clem is back and she's back in black, you're gonna love her 'new' character. You'll meet some ol' friends and enemies, and if you have your Season 1 and 400 Days saves - the game will continue directly based upon your choices in previous Telltale TWD games. Characters are portrayed pretty nicely, most of 'em are not flat and you'll have your own satisfaction or disappointment with their destinies and what you choose for them, and that thing is pretty important when it comes to games that are story and emotions driven.The Walking Dead Season 2 needs some more action, but it gets you pretty pumped up with a story and therefore, I can't really complain. It's violent and hectic and if you love the world of TWD comics - this, in a pretty good way, comes pretty close.Either way, you have to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ crazy not to acknowledge the following - AMC's should seek game producers to work for their show, because this is WAY BETTER than that lame a$$ stuff served for fourth year now. If you've played Season 1 - get it. If you did not - get Season 1 first.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												I'm assuming anyone that reads this review has played the original game. Spoilers will be your undoing if you read on and haven't played the original all the way through yet.This season had a lot of hard choices in it. I'm not sure if my choices actually mattered at all honestly. Similar to the first game come to think of it like how even if you chose not to rob the station wagon you would rob the station wagon anyway because your friends would ignore you and take it's contents or how if you saved Ben he just died very soon after anyway. But you still feel like your participation mattered.The layout of the dialoge options were different from part 1. In part 1 I had gotten used to tapping 1-4 to repond with the choice I wanted to use. In part 2 you get clickable boxes instead. It's a minor difference I guess.Otherwise the gameplay is a lot more of the same as part 1; walk around until you trigger an event and mix the occassional quicktime event into the formula.As I play I do moreso feel the nagging feeling that my actions in this game (including part 1) don't effect anything. There comes a point in part 2 where it's obvious where things are headed and as much as I try to steer it away -- whether by calming things down, arguing against, or getting physically involved -- it barrels straight into the bad time I saw coming a mile away. In the finale I had the option to be the reason for the bad time or just sit back and let the bad time happen because of someone else while I looked away. In other words when it comes down to the nitty gritty I feel as much as I do get into the game it doesn't actually let me get that interactive. I can change minor details - such as what side I take when arguments take place - but not major ones like the outcome of the arguments or the actions that follow said arguments.Ultimately I should consider it more of a movie than a game and not truely expect to change the outcome. And as an interactive movie I see it still as a very good movie. by game standards I'd give it 3/10, but as an interactive movie - which is truely what it shines as - I'd give it a 8/10.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												After the first season of Walking Dead I was keen to see the way the second played out. Without giving anything away in terms of plot, the writers are keen to show a frank and thorough storyline and this starting episode doesn't disappoint. Much time is taken to allow the characters to show their personalities, even a subtle nuance in a character allows us to make our own choices. Its choices that rule this game - every player has his or her way of playing. Drama is at its highest as we have come to expect from this series.The only gripe I have is the revised control system, which I didn't find that responsive and there were a few keys moments where I had to go back to complete the scene because of this. Some of the language used in one of the menus I don't think translates very well to a European English audience as it didn't give a clear outcome of what would happen when was pressed, again making me replay sections of the game. For me, this is a minor detail - that being said I think the season one controls were fine and didn't need a rehash.For anyone who has played the series this is a must - and if you haven't please start with season one! Well recommended.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												So, one question you could possibly have on your mind is: how does this game stack up against it's predecessor? If you want the short version, they added/improved a lot of game mechanics, but the game only goes downhill from there. Keep reading if you want to know more.The UI and other mechanics have been enhanced slightly, you no longer have to walk everywhere as there is now "fast-walking" which can be used by holding down shift.  Selecting dialouge options is easier, as well as the various actions you can perform on characters, they changed it all to cursor based so you can click on each option independently, instead of having to use the mouse wheel. Quick reaction times also got some love, as now in some cases you need to use WASD to move out of the way, but I wouldn't consider this a breakthrough or anything special, I'm just putting it out there on the table.Now that we've gone through the good, here comes the bad...the actual story and episodes. I really liked the first 2 episodes, the first most of all but after those two, everything just started to seem...I don't know...off? I can't really describe it, maybe it's just because in the first season I felt like I had more freedom, and as I went through the episodes it was like my freedom to make certain choices and my ability to move around freely just seemed to be near diminished. The last episode seemed to be the worst in terms of choice making. Why couldn't I just shoot Arvo? I wanted him dead for the longest time. Why did I have to choose between shooting Kenny and Jane? Kenny proved he was unstable, so I ended up offing him, then it turns out Jane was being just as big of a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥as Kenny was? Just to prove her point that he was unstable?? I applaud telltale for making a series as complex as this, but I would seriously prefer it if they take their time with the next season. I was honestly surprised when Episode 5 released when it did, just one month after Episode 4, I expected it to take MUCH longer than that, and it probably should have.Anyhow, I will most likely be picking up Season 3, despite the slight dissapointment I obtained from playing this one. If Season 3 turns out to be very similar to this one, I don't think I'll be playing the series anymore. Do I still recommend the game? Yes, it's still an enjoyable title, it's just not as enjoyable and memorable as the first title.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												The Walking Dead is the pinnacle of modern day point-and-click adventure games. Its strongpoint is its dynamic storytelling and character development, which are tailored to player choice, not unlike role-playing games. This game creates characters better than most others, they feel more alive than any other game due to how responsive they are to your dialogue choices. Combined with the intensity of the plot, The Walking Dead is one of the easiest games to connect to, rivaled only by some of Bioware's RPGs. It's a definite must-have for any gamer, no matter how experienced you are. The Walking Dead is an interactive story, much better than the television show, and it's a fine demonstration of how good and personal video game storytelling can be.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Amazing, I recommend this to anyone and everyone who has an appreciation for fine storytelling. Think of it as a mix between a Heavy Rain, Sam and Max, and of course, The Walking Dead. In this game your choices actually matter, they have an impact on what the rest of your game will be like, which is not something you see everyday. The cell shaded art style gives it a unique comic book feel, wish makes it stick to it's roots from The Walking Dead comic, which is nice, sometimes it can draw you away from the experience but overall it doesn't matter. Asides a few technical bugs, like characters disappearing and re-appearing, there is nothing that extremely catches your attention. The characters though, damn, playing as Clementine and choosing sides (or being neutral) between different characters throughout the game builds more of a relationship, and brings you more in-depth with how people are affected by the apocalypse. This is great so far, you'll see when you play it for yourself. which you sure as hell should do.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												The Walking Dead: Season 2 is a good game, but not as good as season 1. The story doesn't catch you as much as season 1 does.One funny fact: You don't need the save game file of season 1 at all. If you start playing season 2 the game searches for a save game file of season 1. If the game found it you have to chose the save game file. In season 1 I have 2 different save game files. On my 2nd walkthrough I always have chosen other answers, for example in my first walkthrough I let Lee slowly turning into a walker and on my 2nd walkthrough I shot him in the end. Now to the funny part: After having chosen your save game file, the season 2 game always shows (in a short way) what happened in season 1, ALWAYS showing Lee in the end slowly turning into a walker even if you may have shot him in the end. That is why you don't need season 1 and I do not know why the game searches for a season 1 save game file.And my second funny fact: Some answer options are absolutely unnessecary. An example: In the beginning of the game I answered Christa something about Omid when we were in the woods. It showed "Christa will remember that", but damn it, you don't see Christa in the entire game anymore, so where da **** will she remember it? There are several situations like that where it shows "X/Y will remember it", but 1 moment later the person is gone for the entire game or is dead 2 seconds later. Maybe some decisions are important for the future season, but as you don't need season 1 at all maybe you don't need season 2 at all for season 3 which would be really really bad because there are 5 possible endings in season 2. If season 3 starts randomly in a place where you shouldn't be because of the ending you have chosen, then it is an epic fail. :PAnyway, it's a nice game, has a nice setting, but doesn't catch you as season 1 did. I'm a big fan of The Walking Dead, loved season 1 and I had to buy season 2. It is still alright to play it, but season 1 was better. :) Still, those who played season 1 must buy this game. :)

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												REVIEW OF EPISODE 1 + 2 ONLY! (ONLY ONES OUT AS OF NOW)I will update this in future.If you liked Season 1, you should buy this right away, if you never played Season 1 it's probably best you play Season 1 first since it's so great and has a great story that continues into this and your choices from that game affect this game.Episode 1 lasts like 1 Hour 40 Minutes. Episode 2 lasts about 2 Hours.The story continues from Season 1. Clementine, Omed and pregnent Christa are trying to survive.You play as the now 10 year old girl Clementine in a zombie (Refered to as Walkers/Lurkers) apocalyse.In a series of events, Clementine is parted from Omed and Christa and meets with a whole new group and a famillar face, this game is so tense and has to be the most amazing game I've ever played.The gameplay of this game is amazing and fits in very well with the cutscenes, during these cutscenes you choose what your character says and does and what you do Seriously affects the story, no crap just your own experience in the zombie apocalyse. The game outside these cutscenes takes the form of Point and Click, click on things, collect and click on more things but the game is so fun and the story is so interesting that this never gets boring.The game runs better, a lot of new gameplay feautures have been added and the graphics have been given an amazing update from last year.You HAVE to get this game if you played Season 1, don't end it there!Amazing so far and there's another 3 episodes still to come!

content:
Posted: March 1
												I called the first season one of the most emotional games I've ever played. So, my standards for this one going in were extremely high. It was probably impossible to ever have met them. But it's not just that season two isn't as good as the first one. It's not very good at all.The problem I have with a lot of zombie fiction is how self-serious and forcibly edgy it can get. The Walking Dead show and comic suffer terribly from this at time, but the first season of the game managed to mostly avoid that. There was hope, there was humanity, but there was still that dark, ugly side that we all love the genre for. People died suddenly and terribly. It was sad. The characters were imperfect and divisive, but they felt human. Which made it all the harder to see them go.But this time around, it just seems like much of the cast is only there to die. They get a single personality trait, and then development gets tossed aside in favour of counting down the minutes until another one of them is torn apart or whatever. I'm sitting here trying to remember anything about some of them aside from how they died. There were plenty of shocking moments, but they came so often and without any weight to them that it hit that terrible, damning point overly bleak stuff like this can reach: I stopped caring. I was no longer worried about the cast (aside from Clem herself) and didn't care who lived or died anymore. There was no one to root for but her, and the plot seemed to be going absolutely nowhere aside from the group walking forward.One major character seemed to be written to be intentionally divisive. You'll know who I mean once you meet them. But the way it's done feels clumsy and irritating. Which is a problem when a huge amount of the drama unfolding centres around this one person. I was just exhausted listening to them speak by the end. That said, the season does have a really strong opening episode. It's harrowing and brutal and tense all throughout. Just like the rest of the season should have been. But after that, it becomes a parade of meaningless death without any real purpose. The first season had a goal, even if it wasn't a very good one, had a main character with a purpose, and it had a proper arc to the overall plot. But this one is just meandering for four episodes before they decide that's all, folks. Also disappointing: most of the cast introduced in the 400 days add-on for the first season is absent or irrelevant. That DLC had a lot of cool mini-stories that I would have liked to see developed more. One character does return full-time, but the rest are forgotten. I'm still a big fan of what Telltale is doing in their other stuff, and I don't have any technical or gameplay complaints to bring up. But I have to say they totally lost me here. It just felt like they didn't know where to go with things and the edge was just too strong to take this season seriously or invest myself emotionally. Which is probably good, because I don't think I could take being as devastated as last time all over again.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												I for one love The Walking Dead: Season 2. Definately worth the purchase! The storyline is definately the reason I keep coming back for more with beautifully developed individuals, personalities, situations, choices and plot progression. (( BEFORE YOU PURCHASE: It would be well worth your time and your money to BUY and PLAY the FIRST game before Season 2 . The choices you make in the first game carry on through to this game! - If you don't, the choices from the firstgame are generated randomly, so its worth buying the first for the emotional connection to the characters, the tough choices you made and seeing the direct consequences of those!))Alittle different to the first game, also a firm favourite game, in terms of the game interface, instead clicking on the option boxes rather than scrolling through the choices. A little odd to begin with but I found it extremely easy to click back into.The graphics are definately easy on the eye and again, my favourite artstyle in a game for a long time. (And it mirrors the Grahic Novels of The Walking Dead. Lets not bring up huge collection of artwork and books from the series that is threatening to cave in the floorboards of my room... haha...) The choices you make, the visuals and the audio is fantastic and credit must go to the entire developement team! Overal, I definately believe people must try this game! If you prefer games such as Call of Duty, Battlefeild or anything in that style in online multiplayer, then it may not be your go-to choice but if you are anything like myself you will like this game. If you love games with character, plot and consequences, this game is definately for you! The characters reach out and touch the sections of your soul that are usually reserved for close friends and family, especially when you have played the first game! I'm not one to demand, but go play this game! Haha! Till next time, Can't wait for Episode 3 to hit the store! ~Ree

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												If you've made it to the second game, you probably already know this is hardly a game at all.  More like a choose-your-own-comic-game.  If for some reason you stumble on this review having never played Season One or Season Two, I recommend checking to see if this is even your thing.  With that out of the way...Season Two was even better than Season One, mainly because of the change of protagonist.  Not that there was anything wrong with Lee, but playing as an eleven-year-old girl is so much more interesting.  Clem is inherently and automatically so powerless in some situations, and yet incredibly powerful in ways you wouldn't expect.  That's one reason that makes this one of the more interesting narratives in all of gaming right now.  If... you call this gaming.I can't comment on the extent of the branching story, because I have and probably will only play this once for a long while.  However, I imagine it's probably a fair amount of illusion of choice going on.  Nonetheless, this is worth your time.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Season 2 of The Walking Dead continues where you left off in episode one, this time from the prespective of Clementine. The interface is largely the same, with a little bit of modernization in terms of look and feel of the UI, and a stronger sense they are eschewing some of the more traditional puzzler mechanics in favor of storytelling.And that they do well. In the conclusion I found myself unconciously making choices not on what I thought my desired "win state" was, but instead what was the right way for The Walking Dead, and in so doing found a very satisifying emotional experience; one that made me think of what would happen to the characters as a result. Brilliant, emotional storytelling.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												                                  THIS IS A SERIOUS REVIEW, THIS IS NOT SUPPOSED TO MAKE YOU LAUGH                                                  I didn't believe that this season was going to be better than season one, but man, was i SO WRONG. Yeah, i kinda missed playing as Lee, but playing as Clementine and seeing how much she has matured from the first season is awesome, and it's awesome playing as her. This Season has as much tear jerking scenes as the first one, and if there isn't the same amount, then it is more tear jerking.In my Opinion, the Season started off a little bit slow, but every episode got better and better, then Episode 5 comes out and just blows me away. If you have not played the first season, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND playing it before this season, so you develop the relationship with Clementine and other Characters. Some Characters that are in the first season are back in this season, so prepare your♥♥♥♥♥♥for some tears.If you don't have this game, it is a must buy, even if you aren't a fan of the TV series, chances are you will still fall in the love with this game. This is a game about building relationships with the characters and storyline, if you just like running and gunning games like Call of Duty, then this game isn't for you, but if you do love storylines and building relationships with characters, then this game is for you.I'd give this game a perfect 10/10, the ending had me in more tears than the first one, and i can tell you,♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan in Episode 5. Last thing is last, if you read this full review, thank you for taking your time to read this entire thing, you are awesome.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												What I love about this series is how it's story captures me and places me in the situation of how I would actually react to this in real life. You have to consider long-term effects, morals, etc. of your group and decide what you think is best to survive. It is linear in the aspect of things will happen, no matter what choice you take, but it's who you take with you to the end that matters and what type of person you choose to be. There were quite a few heart-warming scenes, and a few that made me sick... but that a game can make me feel so much makes it worth the money. You don't get stories like these in games anymore.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Season 2 of the Walking Dead starts off very well, episode 1 really got me in terms of emotions. I especially enjoyed episode 2, however later episodes get a little boring and repetitive. The final episode makes up for it though.The interactive parts have been nicely improved since the first season, but there's also much less exploration you can do. There are some tough decisions to be made and consequences to deal with, which really affect the story and leave you wondering if you made the right decision... as once again, people's lives depend on you.I really enjoyed playing this one, it might not be as truly amazing as season 1, but if you liked the first season, it's a must-play. Some games can really mess with your emotions, this is definitely one of those that you won't forget.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												The Walking Dead: Season 2 is an epic drama encapsulating the life of a little girl called Clementine. The game includes difficult choices that ultimately lead to dangerous consequences. However you play it, there will always be hard decisions that require a lot of attention.This incredible Telltale game carries on from the previous storyline of Season 1.I would definitely recommend the game to anyone who has played Season 1 and wants to give it a try,(however if you are thinking of getting Season 2 first, I wouldn't because the gameplay of Season 1 will ultimately affect this gameplay,) personally I bought it during a sale, when it was reduced to £4.99, and I feel as if this game should be worth £15.00 on steam instead of full price of £18.99, but that's just my opinion.There are 5 acts in this great game, however Act 1 and 2 didn't really impress me, the gameplay seemed slow and the decisions that needed to be made were relatively simple, and didn't come at a huge cost. However Acts 3, 4 and 5 were much better, with a better more adaptable storyline with more action and more difficult decisions.Personally I played this game quite passively and tried to stay out of combat too much, whilst trying to make friends with everyone and not get in their way, however I couldn't do this for the whole game as some decisions required me to choose 1 side.The improved gameplay from the first Season also made it stand out more and the Main Menu and UI was improved from the previous season.I finished the game within a week of buying it, and although it may be a short playtime, it makes up for in gameplay.Looking forward to Season 3 and hopefully it will be as good as the previous 2!!!Overall I give this game a 9.1/10!!!! The only fault of this game would be watching the credits after every Act, as it gets a bit repetitive! SPOILER ALERT: Lee will be met again sometime in this playthrough!!!

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Season 2 is not like Season 1. Let's get that out of the way now; the tone is much darker than the previous installment in the series, and much of this is due to the character whose eyes you see the world through. In Season 1, you play as Lee, a good man who made a huge mistake, who tries his best to protect his friends and, specifically, a little girl named Clementine. After an emotional roller coaster of a season, we have no idea who among the group survives, with the exception of Clementine, who has survived the ordeal of the finale to enter into a new and uncertain place. In Season 2, you ARE Clementine. During the whole of Season 2, you experience all the horrors of a world gone mad. However, there is no one to shield you from the darkness; despite still being a child, your Clementine has to experience the weight of adult decisions made in a nightmare world. Season 2 is at times visceral, nihilistic, and genuinely painful to get through, especially if you developed any sort of affinity towards Clementine in the prior season. You'll meet all sorts of engaging characters, both old and new, but you'll often watch as they are quickly and brutally snuffed out, just another casualty in this constantly expanding hell on earth. The quicktime events compliment the narrative action well, though they feel more frequent and more urgent, as protecting Clementine from zombies suddenly becomes a direct survival experience. Rather than seeking to save someone from life as a member of the undead in a way that was so common in Season 1, you're often trying to save yourself from death while managing the fates of others.Here's a brief spoiler: everybody dies. This game does a great job of hammering home the futility of life in this particular narrative world, both in the grand scheme of things and in the eyes of others, but it manages to make most deaths hit hard until it finally numbs you to the sensation of watching the life leave another character's eyes. By the end of Episode 5, I felt somewhat hollow and broken, as I was no longer able to trust my naturally altruistic intuition. During these episodes, you are betrayed, lied to, and ultimately left staring into the abyss as friends fall around you. I went from trusting the group, always following the altruistic path of the "hero," to slowly descending into pure self-preservation, ignoring my previous instincts of group protection and "doing the right thing" for the sake of surviving. This season's story is well-told, and though it has some occasional weak points (Too many of the events seem overly emotional on the brink of pure manipulation, when a less heavy-handed approach might have done), it is a fantastic tale that will affect you in ways the good literature should. I highly recommend it in all the ways I would recommend a good book, as this is not a video game in a traditional sense. If you're looking for an affecting, well-written story that will make you consider both your place in the world and the true disposition of your heart, give this one a try.

												Review written after completing the game, I have also played the first game.I AM NOT GOING TO SPOIL ANYTHING.This game goes away from the first games exploration and puzzle solving decision making to a heavy focus on story and dialogue.Overall impression:During my playtrough I felt hindered by the designers, most of my time was spent with dialogue. Now there is nothing wrong with that, I enjoy Telltales way of making dialogue quite a lot but when the decision making left to the player is minimal and  has no large impact on how the story progresses you kind of feel bored with the actions the player can make in conversation.(Obviously there are big decisions but the majority of the game does not have the same feeling as conversation in the Walking Dead (1)).More depth:My biggest problem with The Walking Dead Season 2 is how ridiculously linear the levels are, there are not areas for you to explore there is only areas for you to press W until you reach the next queue for more dialogue. In The Walking Dead (the first game) you were more free to roam around and find mission objectives and you could decide to listen to your friends and get more mission objectives but obviously exposing yourself to more risk. That is what this game lacks, exploration and more variation on how to influence the world around you.Tl;dr:If you want to find out about what happens to Clementine then pick this game up. I just wish they had more exploration and more depth to the conversations. It does not feel like the first Walking Dead Game in my opinion but it is a good game non the less.8/10 and that is in comparison to 10/10 for The Walking Dead (1)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												tl;dr: generally okay season, but don't go into it expecting it to be as good as season 1.The season isn't even done yet, we still have one unreleased episode at the moment, but I still feel like I know enough to say that it probably will not be worth it. Season 2 does not live up to the impression Season 1 left on me, and, as a whole, I think I liked the season 2 cast more. But it doesn't matter, in the end. We complain about our choices not mattering in Season 1, because no matter what you do, everything converges onto one point by Episode 5 - Omid and Christa make it out of Savannah, and Lee sacrifices himself for Clementine. But never have I had so many of my choices invalidated in one episode than in Season 2. Having just played Episode 4 - nothing I did mattered that episode. None of my choices. Major characters dying without speaking lines, major characters dying in the most bogus ways possible, yet Telltale still tries to pass it off as shock factor.And at this point? It's not. I played Season 1, and I know it's the zombie apocalypse and that people are going to die. Maybe that's meta gaming, but it's going into the game knowing exactly what I bought. I bought the game for the cast I knew I'd eventually come to love. The cast I knew I was going to die, but I knew I'd do my best to keep them alive. The cast I wanted to get to know, the stories of the survivors I wanted to hear. We get... almost none of that, here. In Episode 4, we get more about one character's backstory (whom we met in the previous episode) shoehorned into 90 minutes of gameplay than we have any of the other characters we've spent the rest of the season with. Only for that character to bow out, because she 'doesn't want to see Clem fall.' Ridiculous.The writing is good, when it wants to be. When it needs to be, it falls flat. Characters completely change their personalities between episodes without us knowing why or seeing how - because they're off screen 75% of the time. There are significantly less hubs in Season 2 than there were in Season 1, meaning you barely get to talk to these characters when they are on screen. And when you do get to talk to them, you get one line, one subject, then it's done. But yeah, the story is still as emotional, but now I don't know if I'm crying at a character's death because I'm genuinely sad they're dead - or because I'm disappointed at the loss of potential.At the time of this review, the day of Episode 4's release, I can say I'm not excited for Episode 5 at all. Let it come, let me cry, let it be over.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												Like all Telltale reviews, by now you should know what you're getting. It's a playable story with limited decisions that you play for the story and good voice acting. So what's up with TWD Season 2? It's good. Not quite as good as Season 1, TWD2 is still a worthy title. I don't think you can call this game "fun". After all, the choices are depressing. Your ability to actually change things is exceptionally limited. It's more of an interactive story than a game. Still, I find this series compelling to play and the narrative gripping. Clem is one of my most favorite characters in all my gaming years (stretching back to Pong). The voice acting continues to be a major strength of the series. I found Season 2's quality more variable than Season 1. There were far more gut-punches in #1, far more difficult decisions in #1 than in this season. Still, this has it's moments. But frankly perhaps the biggest flaw is that there are too many characters that you don't really get to know them. They seem - and often are - expendible whereas in Season #1 the group was tighter and better fleshed out.If you haven't played Season 1, get that first. But these titles are really worth your time because they tell such great stories.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												SPOILERSShort Version: An exceedingly good game let down by a couple of tiny gripes for me. The characters aren't as accessible, and the story moves too fast, taking the grim, tense slog out of the post-apocalyptic world. The Walking Dead Game: Season Two was a game I awaiting with my teeth buried into my knuckles in anticipation, staring at the calendar for each episode of the five-part season. Prior to playing I had some serious fears for the game, not least that it was following The Walking Dead Game: Season One, which was most probably my favourite game of 2012, so well done Telltale for that. Suffice it to say therefore that Season Two had some huge booties to fill. For me there are two things that prevent Season Two from achieving this. One is something that I can explain myself to an extent, but it nevertheless does bite at my immersion-loving ankles, the other is perhaps the most surprising qualm I've ever had with a game. Enough build up. Problem one. One of my favourite aspects of Season One was having a wealth of moments where your entire group was sat milling around by a broken-down train, or hiding out in a drug store. As Lee you could seize these moments of tranquillity and have a chat with all of your companions. Not only was there ample supply of these moments, but the conversations themselves were full of options so you could get to know your fellow man/woman/child/Ben. Having long, character defining conversations, where each character could say something to entirely change how you see them, for better or worse was one of the most engrossing things about Season One for me. It made each moment with them matter. They could reveal themselves to be a closet racist, or a snobbish elitist at heart, or they could show a depth of empathy and caring you'd not expected from them and never would have. However, in Season Two, these conversation moments are whittled down, instead with a heavier focus on story (more on that later). While this could not necessarily be a bad thing (more story, more value for money etc) it means that I never felt much for any of the characters. While every death in Season One struck me in some way, characters came and went in Season Two like cars on a motorway. At some points I barely had time to remember their names and 'poof', they were dead or split off or otherwise departed. This meant that even as far as Episode Five people could die and my reaction was the same as if I'd just watched them scratch their chin. Given that by the timescale of Season Two, the zombie apocalypse has been cracking on for a good year and then some, so perhaps this less talkative batch of people works; everyone's realised that getting to know people well isn't a worthwhile investment. But it still makes the game feel shallow to me (by comparison with Season One, it's still gloriously rich compared with most, don't get me wrong).That's problem that I can explain myself. Problem two though is a baffler. Due to the lack of slow, conversational moments to regulate the pace of the story, Season Two barrels through what I could have happily seen spread over Season Two and Three really. Yup, too much plot! So much happens in such a short space of play-time that, even though your character has gone through more ordeals than you can shake a dismembered limb at, I still felt cheated at the end. I finished the finale (which is a gloriously heart-breaking set of decisions that caused me a have a very restless night's sleep, so applause for you again Telltale, I'd ruffle your hair were you here), and looking back over the game, felt like I'd played the Cliff Notes version of the story, rather than the full text. There was so much potential for character development and building some horrific tension and decision-making into Carver's community. I'd happily have stayed there and let characters evolve and come to terms/blows with the situation a lot more. But the story seemed to feel the need to charge headlong onwards. Exploring Carver's world could have been fantastic, but it's gone now. Shame. My main gripe story wise was that it became suddenly very linear. I saw an opportunity with Carver in Episode Three. My Clementine was by that point a cold, logical, unshakable zombie/bandit annihilation machine, and I saw the opportunity to stick with Carver. You want to survive, you join the winning side. To hell with the broken people you started out with. Life is for those who can keep it. But I was funnelled into making a decision I didn't particularly want to make, and this probably soured much of Episode Four for me. However those are just two small(ish) issues that, because I'm a whiny git, I'm blowing out of proportion. The Walking Dead Game: Season Two is a fantastically made game, which slicker graphics, faster paced action and drama, and the same tough decisions, which ACTUALLY HAVE AN EFFECT on the outcome this time. I'm perhaps overly critical on what I'd consider issues that spoilt what would have definitely been my favourite game of 2014. If it had stayed a little truer to Season One, with a batch of characters I could get to know, it would have been a marvel of just how phenomenal a game could be. Instead, it's just very, very good. Given what it could have been, being an 8/9 out of 10 game is somehow a disappointment.

												Taking off where the Season One left, Season Two lets you control Clementine, the adorable little girl you have fiercely tried to protect in the previous season. While the world stil lies in ruins and zombies are creeping at every corner, Clementine will struggle against the odds while wandering the wilderness, encountering new characters and making new bonds with them through an epic storyline. Controlling Clementine drastically alters the combat mechanics, while you will try to escape the fight or use the environment to better against the odds. Immerse story, skillfully written dialogue and an adorable but sturdy protagonist will make yourself lost in the atmosphere of a dark and desperate world.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												If you've made it to the second game, you probably already know this is hardly a game at all.  More like a choose-your-own-comic-game.  If for some reason you stumble on this review having never played Season One or Season Two, I recommend checking to see if this is even your thing.  With that out of the way...Season Two was even better than Season One, mainly because of the change of protagonist.  Not that there was anything wrong with Lee, but playing as an eleven-year-old girl is so much more interesting.  Clem is inherently and automatically so powerless in some situations, and yet incredibly powerful in ways you wouldn't expect.  That's one reason that makes this one of the more interesting narratives in all of gaming right now.  If... you call this gaming.I can't comment on the extent of the branching story, because I have and probably will only play this once for a long while.  However, I imagine it's probably a fair amount of illusion of choice going on.  Nonetheless, this is worth your time.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												The Walking Dead: Season 2 is an epic drama encapsulating the life of a little girl called Clementine. The game includes difficult choices that ultimately lead to dangerous consequences. However you play it, there will always be hard decisions that require a lot of attention.This incredible Telltale game carries on from the previous storyline of Season 1.I would definitely recommend the game to anyone who has played Season 1 and wants to give it a try,(however if you are thinking of getting Season 2 first, I wouldn't because the gameplay of Season 1 will ultimately affect this gameplay,) personally I bought it during a sale, when it was reduced to £4.99, and I feel as if this game should be worth £15.00 on steam instead of full price of £18.99, but that's just my opinion.There are 5 acts in this great game, however Act 1 and 2 didn't really impress me, the gameplay seemed slow and the decisions that needed to be made were relatively simple, and didn't come at a huge cost. However Acts 3, 4 and 5 were much better, with a better more adaptable storyline with more action and more difficult decisions.Personally I played this game quite passively and tried to stay out of combat too much, whilst trying to make friends with everyone and not get in their way, however I couldn't do this for the whole game as some decisions required me to choose 1 side.The improved gameplay from the first Season also made it stand out more and the Main Menu and UI was improved from the previous season.I finished the game within a week of buying it, and although it may be a short playtime, it makes up for in gameplay.Looking forward to Season 3 and hopefully it will be as good as the previous 2!!!Overall I give this game a 9.1/10!!!! The only fault of this game would be watching the credits after every Act, as it gets a bit repetitive! SPOILER ALERT: Lee will be met again sometime in this playthrough!!!

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												If you've made it to the second game, you probably already know this is hardly a game at all.  More like a choose-your-own-comic-game.  If for some reason you stumble on this review having never played Season One or Season Two, I recommend checking to see if this is even your thing.  With that out of the way...Season Two was even better than Season One, mainly because of the change of protagonist.  Not that there was anything wrong with Lee, but playing as an eleven-year-old girl is so much more interesting.  Clem is inherently and automatically so powerless in some situations, and yet incredibly powerful in ways you wouldn't expect.  That's one reason that makes this one of the more interesting narratives in all of gaming right now.  If... you call this gaming.I can't comment on the extent of the branching story, because I have and probably will only play this once for a long while.  However, I imagine it's probably a fair amount of illusion of choice going on.  Nonetheless, this is worth your time.

												What I love about this series is how it's story captures me and places me in the situation of how I would actually react to this in real life. You have to consider long-term effects, morals, etc. of your group and decide what you think is best to survive. It is linear in the aspect of things will happen, no matter what choice you take, but it's who you take with you to the end that matters and what type of person you choose to be. There were quite a few heart-warming scenes, and a few that made me sick... but that a game can make me feel so much makes it worth the money. You don't get stories like these in games anymore.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												The Walking Dead: Season 2 is an epic drama encapsulating the life of a little girl called Clementine. The game includes difficult choices that ultimately lead to dangerous consequences. However you play it, there will always be hard decisions that require a lot of attention.This incredible Telltale game carries on from the previous storyline of Season 1.I would definitely recommend the game to anyone who has played Season 1 and wants to give it a try,(however if you are thinking of getting Season 2 first, I wouldn't because the gameplay of Season 1 will ultimately affect this gameplay,) personally I bought it during a sale, when it was reduced to £4.99, and I feel as if this game should be worth £15.00 on steam instead of full price of £18.99, but that's just my opinion.There are 5 acts in this great game, however Act 1 and 2 didn't really impress me, the gameplay seemed slow and the decisions that needed to be made were relatively simple, and didn't come at a huge cost. However Acts 3, 4 and 5 were much better, with a better more adaptable storyline with more action and more difficult decisions.Personally I played this game quite passively and tried to stay out of combat too much, whilst trying to make friends with everyone and not get in their way, however I couldn't do this for the whole game as some decisions required me to choose 1 side.The improved gameplay from the first Season also made it stand out more and the Main Menu and UI was improved from the previous season.I finished the game within a week of buying it, and although it may be a short playtime, it makes up for in gameplay.Looking forward to Season 3 and hopefully it will be as good as the previous 2!!!Overall I give this game a 9.1/10!!!! The only fault of this game would be watching the credits after every Act, as it gets a bit repetitive! SPOILER ALERT: Lee will be met again sometime in this playthrough!!!

Posted: January 12, 2015
												A little bit shorter than the first season, but packs an equally powerful emotional punch.It's common knowledge by now that Telltale has never been known for explosive or exciting gameplay, but that's hardly ever been the point. When you find yourself as deeply engrossed in a game's plot as this, things like "pulling off awesome headshots" or "badass stealth kills" fall by the wayside. The Walking Dead games I feel I can safely recommend to anyone with heart and an appreciation for good storytelling (which, should really be everyone). I myself, have never cared for TWD TV series, nor have I read the comics, and I can't really say I'm a point-and-click gamer, but I have nonetheless been enjoying the $h!t out of this series.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Season 2 of The Walking Dead continues where you left off in episode one, this time from the prespective of Clementine. The interface is largely the same, with a little bit of modernization in terms of look and feel of the UI, and a stronger sense they are eschewing some of the more traditional puzzler mechanics in favor of storytelling.And that they do well. In the conclusion I found myself unconciously making choices not on what I thought my desired "win state" was, but instead what was the right way for The Walking Dead, and in so doing found a very satisifying emotional experience; one that made me think of what would happen to the characters as a result. Brilliant, emotional storytelling.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												tl;dr: generally okay season, but don't go into it expecting it to be as good as season 1.The season isn't even done yet, we still have one unreleased episode at the moment, but I still feel like I know enough to say that it probably will not be worth it. Season 2 does not live up to the impression Season 1 left on me, and, as a whole, I think I liked the season 2 cast more. But it doesn't matter, in the end. We complain about our choices not mattering in Season 1, because no matter what you do, everything converges onto one point by Episode 5 - Omid and Christa make it out of Savannah, and Lee sacrifices himself for Clementine. But never have I had so many of my choices invalidated in one episode than in Season 2. Having just played Episode 4 - nothing I did mattered that episode. None of my choices. Major characters dying without speaking lines, major characters dying in the most bogus ways possible, yet Telltale still tries to pass it off as shock factor.And at this point? It's not. I played Season 1, and I know it's the zombie apocalypse and that people are going to die. Maybe that's meta gaming, but it's going into the game knowing exactly what I bought. I bought the game for the cast I knew I'd eventually come to love. The cast I knew I was going to die, but I knew I'd do my best to keep them alive. The cast I wanted to get to know, the stories of the survivors I wanted to hear. We get... almost none of that, here. In Episode 4, we get more about one character's backstory (whom we met in the previous episode) shoehorned into 90 minutes of gameplay than we have any of the other characters we've spent the rest of the season with. Only for that character to bow out, because she 'doesn't want to see Clem fall.' Ridiculous.The writing is good, when it wants to be. When it needs to be, it falls flat. Characters completely change their personalities between episodes without us knowing why or seeing how - because they're off screen 75% of the time. There are significantly less hubs in Season 2 than there were in Season 1, meaning you barely get to talk to these characters when they are on screen. And when you do get to talk to them, you get one line, one subject, then it's done. But yeah, the story is still as emotional, but now I don't know if I'm crying at a character's death because I'm genuinely sad they're dead - or because I'm disappointed at the loss of potential.At the time of this review, the day of Episode 4's release, I can say I'm not excited for Episode 5 at all. Let it come, let me cry, let it be over.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												SPOILERSShort Version: An exceedingly good game let down by a couple of tiny gripes for me. The characters aren't as accessible, and the story moves too fast, taking the grim, tense slog out of the post-apocalyptic world. The Walking Dead Game: Season Two was a game I awaiting with my teeth buried into my knuckles in anticipation, staring at the calendar for each episode of the five-part season. Prior to playing I had some serious fears for the game, not least that it was following The Walking Dead Game: Season One, which was most probably my favourite game of 2012, so well done Telltale for that. Suffice it to say therefore that Season Two had some huge booties to fill. For me there are two things that prevent Season Two from achieving this. One is something that I can explain myself to an extent, but it nevertheless does bite at my immersion-loving ankles, the other is perhaps the most surprising qualm I've ever had with a game. Enough build up. Problem one. One of my favourite aspects of Season One was having a wealth of moments where your entire group was sat milling around by a broken-down train, or hiding out in a drug store. As Lee you could seize these moments of tranquillity and have a chat with all of your companions. Not only was there ample supply of these moments, but the conversations themselves were full of options so you could get to know your fellow man/woman/child/Ben. Having long, character defining conversations, where each character could say something to entirely change how you see them, for better or worse was one of the most engrossing things about Season One for me. It made each moment with them matter. They could reveal themselves to be a closet racist, or a snobbish elitist at heart, or they could show a depth of empathy and caring you'd not expected from them and never would have. However, in Season Two, these conversation moments are whittled down, instead with a heavier focus on story (more on that later). While this could not necessarily be a bad thing (more story, more value for money etc) it means that I never felt much for any of the characters. While every death in Season One struck me in some way, characters came and went in Season Two like cars on a motorway. At some points I barely had time to remember their names and 'poof', they were dead or split off or otherwise departed. This meant that even as far as Episode Five people could die and my reaction was the same as if I'd just watched them scratch their chin. Given that by the timescale of Season Two, the zombie apocalypse has been cracking on for a good year and then some, so perhaps this less talkative batch of people works; everyone's realised that getting to know people well isn't a worthwhile investment. But it still makes the game feel shallow to me (by comparison with Season One, it's still gloriously rich compared with most, don't get me wrong).That's problem that I can explain myself. Problem two though is a baffler. Due to the lack of slow, conversational moments to regulate the pace of the story, Season Two barrels through what I could have happily seen spread over Season Two and Three really. Yup, too much plot! So much happens in such a short space of play-time that, even though your character has gone through more ordeals than you can shake a dismembered limb at, I still felt cheated at the end. I finished the finale (which is a gloriously heart-breaking set of decisions that caused me a have a very restless night's sleep, so applause for you again Telltale, I'd ruffle your hair were you here), and looking back over the game, felt like I'd played the Cliff Notes version of the story, rather than the full text. There was so much potential for character development and building some horrific tension and decision-making into Carver's community. I'd happily have stayed there and let characters evolve and come to terms/blows with the situation a lot more. But the story seemed to feel the need to charge headlong onwards. Exploring Carver's world could have been fantastic, but it's gone now. Shame. My main gripe story wise was that it became suddenly very linear. I saw an opportunity with Carver in Episode Three. My Clementine was by that point a cold, logical, unshakable zombie/bandit annihilation machine, and I saw the opportunity to stick with Carver. You want to survive, you join the winning side. To hell with the broken people you started out with. Life is for those who can keep it. But I was funnelled into making a decision I didn't particularly want to make, and this probably soured much of Episode Four for me. However those are just two small(ish) issues that, because I'm a whiny git, I'm blowing out of proportion. The Walking Dead Game: Season Two is a fantastically made game, which slicker graphics, faster paced action and drama, and the same tough decisions, which ACTUALLY HAVE AN EFFECT on the outcome this time. I'm perhaps overly critical on what I'd consider issues that spoilt what would have definitely been my favourite game of 2014. If it had stayed a little truer to Season One, with a batch of characters I could get to know, it would have been a marvel of just how phenomenal a game could be. Instead, it's just very, very good. Given what it could have been, being an 8/9 out of 10 game is somehow a disappointment.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Season 2 is not like Season 1. Let's get that out of the way now; the tone is much darker than the previous installment in the series, and much of this is due to the character whose eyes you see the world through. In Season 1, you play as Lee, a good man who made a huge mistake, who tries his best to protect his friends and, specifically, a little girl named Clementine. After an emotional roller coaster of a season, we have no idea who among the group survives, with the exception of Clementine, who has survived the ordeal of the finale to enter into a new and uncertain place. In Season 2, you ARE Clementine. During the whole of Season 2, you experience all the horrors of a world gone mad. However, there is no one to shield you from the darkness; despite still being a child, your Clementine has to experience the weight of adult decisions made in a nightmare world. Season 2 is at times visceral, nihilistic, and genuinely painful to get through, especially if you developed any sort of affinity towards Clementine in the prior season. You'll meet all sorts of engaging characters, both old and new, but you'll often watch as they are quickly and brutally snuffed out, just another casualty in this constantly expanding hell on earth. The quicktime events compliment the narrative action well, though they feel more frequent and more urgent, as protecting Clementine from zombies suddenly becomes a direct survival experience. Rather than seeking to save someone from life as a member of the undead in a way that was so common in Season 1, you're often trying to save yourself from death while managing the fates of others.Here's a brief spoiler: everybody dies. This game does a great job of hammering home the futility of life in this particular narrative world, both in the grand scheme of things and in the eyes of others, but it manages to make most deaths hit hard until it finally numbs you to the sensation of watching the life leave another character's eyes. By the end of Episode 5, I felt somewhat hollow and broken, as I was no longer able to trust my naturally altruistic intuition. During these episodes, you are betrayed, lied to, and ultimately left staring into the abyss as friends fall around you. I went from trusting the group, always following the altruistic path of the "hero," to slowly descending into pure self-preservation, ignoring my previous instincts of group protection and "doing the right thing" for the sake of surviving. This season's story is well-told, and though it has some occasional weak points (Too many of the events seem overly emotional on the brink of pure manipulation, when a less heavy-handed approach might have done), it is a fantastic tale that will affect you in ways the good literature should. I highly recommend it in all the ways I would recommend a good book, as this is not a video game in a traditional sense. If you're looking for an affecting, well-written story that will make you consider both your place in the world and the true disposition of your heart, give this one a try.

Controlling Clementine drastically alters the combat mechanics, while you will try to escape the fight or use the environment to better against the odds. Immerse story, skillfully written dialogue and an adorable but sturdy protagonist will make yourself lost in the atmosphere of a dark and desperate world.

Posted: March 19, 2014
												Usually not a fan or sequal games, as I feel they either deviated too far from the last game, or didn't change enough. Walking Dead so far does a good job of continuing from season 1 and still makes me feel like it's a different game by putting me in the shoes of Clementine instead of the Lee. The Story line doesn't have a linear path which I feel fits the chaotic zombie apocolypse feel. I feel it's a little strange and hard to believe how much faith a group of grown people put in the choices of a 10 year old girl in such a chaotic time however, but would still give this game a solid 8 out of 10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Telltale comes back with the second season of The Walking Dead and it does not disappoint! This season focuses on Clementine and how much she has grown up since the events of season one. She has witnessed some truly horrific events and it has changed her as a person. She is no longer the sweet little girl from the first season. She is willing to do whatever it takes to keep her and her loved ones alive. You meet a lot of new characters that you aren't sure if you will care about them or not. But as you get farther in, you get to know the characters better and you either fall in love with them or hate them. You still choose how the story plays off and some decisions will affect you in later on episodes. There were some very crucial decisions that I don't know if I could even make if I were in Clementine's shoes. Once again the writing and acting is top notch and never failed to entertain me. I was at tears at the end of the last episode and thought the ending had as much as a powerful impact as the first season did. There was a even a moment that made me cringe and it made it even better because it showed how hard it is to do things on your own. One thing I would take off for this season would be that I felt that some of the characters were wasted. I felt that they had more potential/development but suddenly they were just dead. Also, for most things when you make a decision, you basically get the same result if you were to make a different choice. But overall, The Walking Dead Season Two was an awesome experience and I will play it again sometime soon. If you still haven't bought this game, what are you waiting for? Stop reading this really long review and buy it! 8.6/10+ Clementine's Story is amazing.+ Crucial decisions leave you thinking.+ Writing and acting is excellent.+ Has a very high emotional impact.+ Masterful last episode.- Some characters were wasted.- Diverse choices lead to same results.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Before you think about buying this game, I strongly recommend that you buy and play Season One of Telltales The Walking Dead. It is necessary in my opinion. Not only will it help you understand the tone of the game, but it will help you understand who the main protagonist in this game is. TL;DR at the end. Spoilers are marked in  These.	/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////Let me just get this out of the way. No. This game's story is not as good as Season 1. That said, it is hard to beat perfeciton. The story in this game is probably a 9/10, compared to the 10/10 that was S1. You play as Clemintine. Just like the first game, you come across survivors. In the beginning you can see that this group is not as strong as Season 1's group. Thats not me saying these characters are awful. What I am saying is that they are more of a broken group. They may be together, but they each have their own opinion on how to handle things. It is up to you to help guide them along this journey. One of the reasons most people tend to not fancy this season is because of its tonal change. Sure its still about surviving, but its more stressful and less light hearted. For me, that makes sense. The first season was about couping with the way the world has changed and dealing with walkers. In this season, walkers are still an issue, but humans are becoming a real threat. You are always second guessing a new face. Are they friendly? Can we trust them? Should we rob them? This season starts with Clemintine  a few months following the death of Lee.	 You are with two survivors in the beginning  Christa and Omid from Season 1.	 That changes pretty quick though  They don't make it.	 Then you find a new group that you stay with throughout the whole season. I will list some pros and cons from this season of Telltales The Walking Dead.Here are the pros:1.) Clemintine is a great character.2.) The group of survivors are an enjoyble group.3.) The decisions you make matter.4.) Each episode takes place in a new and dangerous setting.5.) Multiple endings.6.) Spoiler  Dream sequence with Lee.	7.) Spoiler  Re-unite with a survivor from Season 1.	8.) Episodes do not drag out as long as some in the first season.9.) Improvements to the controls in this game.10.) Little to not frame rate drops. ( I only experienced one.)Here are the cons:1.) Sarah plz.2.) Some outcomes should have a middle solution.  You should be able to take some of the medicine from Arvo.	3.) Somethings are left unanswered.  Like why was Arvo putting medicince in a trash can? Damn it Arvo!	4.) The last 1/5 of Episode 4 has an intersting conclusion.  Why are the Russians in America? Arvo plz!	5.) Some of the animation is off. Final Thoughts:This is a great game. Its story is darker and more violent than season one, but the characters are still entertaining. The decisions that you make have consequences. The ending to this game is not as black and white as it was in Season 1. SPOILER FOR SEASON 1:  The man who captured Clemintine is a monster. Lee dies no matter what. You must protect/save Clemintine from him.	  The game has a clear good ending though.  It's when you let the Season 1 character kill the Season 2 character. You join them to find the safe place. Then you leave with the Season 1 character.	  It is a huge build up to the ending though. Lots of drama in this game. If you played and enjoyed Season 1, than Season 2 is right for you. If you have never played a Telltale game, then I recommend that you buy Season 1 of Telltales The Walking Dead. It is worth it, and then buy this season. If you did not like Season 1, then  you must hate quality story telling	 this game may not be for you.TL;DR:This is a great game, and a great sequal to an amazing game. It is not the 10/10 that Season 1 is, but its a 9.2/10 at the least. Has a great story, great characters, improved controls, more action, and more walkers. Highly recommended.*Stare back

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												Like all Telltale reviews, by now you should know what you're getting. It's a playable story with limited decisions that you play for the story and good voice acting. So what's up with TWD Season 2? It's good. Not quite as good as Season 1, TWD2 is still a worthy title. I don't think you can call this game "fun". After all, the choices are depressing. Your ability to actually change things is exceptionally limited. It's more of an interactive story than a game. Still, I find this series compelling to play and the narrative gripping. Clem is one of my most favorite characters in all my gaming years (stretching back to Pong). The voice acting continues to be a major strength of the series. I found Season 2's quality more variable than Season 1. There were far more gut-punches in #1, far more difficult decisions in #1 than in this season. Still, this has it's moments. But frankly perhaps the biggest flaw is that there are too many characters that you don't really get to know them. They seem - and often are - expendible whereas in Season #1 the group was tighter and better fleshed out.If you haven't played Season 1, get that first. But these titles are really worth your time because they tell such great stories.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I need to start with the statement that Season Two is still good. However, it's pretty far from the brilliance of Season One. Clem works well as a protagonist and will like to help shape her as she is growing older. However, the dynamic narrative that worked so well between Lee and Clem in the first season is lacking and never made up for.The basic problem of the season is the lack of purpose. You don't have a major goal really at any time, you don't feel like there's a natural flow and so all the little events, personal drama, human loss and so on end up feeling meaningless. The other characters are either unbelievable (so stupid?) or just never fully developed before they disappear and this is in big contrast to Season 1.So as I said, It's definitely worth playing but not nearly as good as the first (7/10).

One of my favorite games. I'll probably end up putting as many hours into this as I did Season 1.[SPOILER ALERT]PROS-+ Another amazing story.+ Story follows Season 1 pretty great.+ I became emotionally attached to more characters.+ Kenny ♥+ Choices from Season 1 are coming back in Season 2.+ Characters will die or live based on your choices.+ I cried again.CONS-- Way too many possible endings: Clementine can be on her own with A.J. She could have left Jane alive but left her. She could have killed both Kenny and Jane and thus being alone with A.J. Clementine can be with Jane and A.J. at Carver's camp and they can let the family stay. Clementine can be with Jane and A.J. at Carver's camp and turn the family away. Clementine can be with Kenny and A.J. after refusing to stay at Wellington. Clementine can be at Wellington with A.J. after leaving Kenny behind.   There's just too much to make a good continuation that flows well into the next (possible) season.9.5/10 - Would Cry With All Endings
