Posted: March 17, 2016
												There are issues - many of them - with Telltale's follow up to one of their most successful titles. Relationships between characters galvanise in tepid fashion regardless of one's choices. Some choices fail to bear the tantalising payoffs that they tease. The supporting cast is no way as endearing enough to care about as their predecessors. Worst of all is the whole pacing of Season Two. But never before has a video game so unapologetically demanded the player to mold a young child in the palm of nightmare. The perennial choice here is define an optimist or a realist of this growing heroine and what type of survivor she will become in a world gone to ruin. Telltale makes an emotional bedrock out of this one particular character portrayal. Yes, guiding sweet Clementine onwards from her tearful ending in Season One is excessively cruel and often heartwrenching, ensuring that by its conclusion the innocence we all desperately wanted to save will be gone forever.

												I don't believe anybody is really interested in reading my humble reviews anyway, but if you really do, then i expect you to have played the first game already. I do try to not spoil that much tho :)Of course i recommend the game. After that badass first game, the second season kept the high standards. The story is, again, very well written and has cliffhangers and unexpected moments everywhere. You can never pretend what is going to happen next. And you really catch yourself being speechless, because something happened you never expected or a situation or reaction didn't turn out as you thought. The developers really created a very thoroughful game. That's for certain.In case of the characters. They are as good as the once from the first game. A lot of different personalities. All as different as a bunch of desperate survivors can be. Some are sad, some are aggressive and some you like the moment you meet them the first time. And yet everybody can change the next moment. It all depends on how you play. Very good job. The graphics are still the same, but that isn't somethign negative per se. If you like that style you are happy if not you are either screwed or you try to deal with it. Trust me after some time you don't even notice it anymore because the story and characters are so fascinating. You just want to get on and on and on :)Some new game mechanics found their way into the game as well. Not many tho. It pretty much is more like a little enhancement. YOu have a wheel now where you can choose from different options that you can perform. Chatting or grabbing or looking. You cann decide it now via a simple mouseclick and don't have to scroll down now. Also there are now some new QTE. You can now dodge here and there and clem can run ...... i wouldn't call it run, but she can move faster now :)Other than that. The game is like the first one. Great. Posted: August 26, 2014
												Just like season 1, I laughed and I cried.. but the second season of this amazing series is unfortunately the weaker of the two, although still a masterpiece in it's own right. The stakes are higher, and while season 1 has you bond with Clementine on a personal level, season 2 directly puts you in her shoes, allowing you to mold and shape her character even further. This was a brilliant move for a variety of reasons, as given Clementine's age, she's physically far weaker than Lee was in season 1. Instead, she has to approach dangerous scenarious by being quick and clever in order to survive, making you feel more helpless than you did in S1. This changes things up a lot and I'm very happy with the direction Telltale took. Additionally, depending on the choices you make during the final episode, you have access to a variety of drastically different endings that from the looks of things, will give everyone a very different season 3, thus increasing the replayability.Well done Telltale.. you've done it again.

Posted: July 5, 2015
Summary (TL;DR)This is the second installment in TellTale's The Walking Dead series, and while I enjoyed the game, I did have my fair share of technical issues that didn't seem to be fixable.If you are reading this and wondering if the 400 Days DLC for Season 1 is worth it, I would say it's a 50/50 chance.The characters from that only make a small appearance with the exclusion of one character, but even with a randomly generated choice for the DLC, the game is still seriously playable without having had that in the first place.There are many jabs and pokes towards characters from the first season, and your choices as Lee have made an effect on Clemintine and how she does things. TTG also cleverly put Clemintine in a few of the same situations as Lee was in, but you will need to keep an eye out for that.If you loved the first season, the second will be just as enjoyable.Pros Great story Great graphics Fairly long gameplay (About 1 1/2 hours per episode) Has achievements Achievements can be earned in a single playthrough Controller support New Improved GUI Choices have a HUGE impact on the series now Many different endings Choices from Season 1 and the 400 days DLC carry over When running into a wall, Clemintine doesn't continue walking to the wall as it was in Season 1.Neutral Points No trading cardsCons Almost every choice you had made with characters from the 400 days DLC doesn't affect gameplay, with the exclusion of one character. Keeps asking for my Save File from Season 1 every time I start a new episode. Scene selection is only available (for me at least) for Episode one. Episode data didn't save when I tried to start the same episode back to where I was Too many different endings, and it will be confusing if you continue to play as Clemintine given all the different outcomes. Minor subtitle issuesRating8/10

Posted: December 30, 2014
												After the long wait for the Season 2, I have finally finished it. I will not give any spoilers, because that is the single-most irritating thing to read if you actually want to read a review. This is the first point-and-click game I've played. The series is enthralling. The first season was driven by the need to save Clementine. Nothing else matters. It was always to ensure her safety. This season manages to be different by mainly being driven by self-preservation. In this way, I do not think it is as emotionally intense, since I make the first-hand decisions to stay alive. Still, I try everything I can to keep those I care about alive, and in brilliantly irritating fashion, sometimes, it's just not possible. The music, is one of the strongest components of the game for me. It is a constant reminder of those left behind and the mistakes made throughout the series. It is truly whelming when the theme music is on and there are times when it makes your heart cringe. People that do not like this style of gaming say they would rather just watch a TV series instead. I can stead-fastly say that this series has captivated me more than any TV show has ever. All I can do now is sit and wait for Season 3 to come out (which I was extastic to hear, has been green-lit). Fantastic story, great music, comic book true graphics, decent character development, and a whole lot of feels, I would 100% recommend this game.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												Following the events and choices of the first season, you take control of Clementine, attempting to survive not only the undead, but also the living in a zombie-plagued world.Improving heavily on the elements of the first season, the second season is worth every dollar and hour you spent on the first - and more.The overall production quality and polish make this season feel more like an interactive movie rather than some convoluted, zombie-filled puzzle game. You can really see and feel the effort that went into improving and out-performing the first season. The choices and story in this season don't feel like they're being sacrificed by obligatory puzzle-game mechanics; and the dialogue doesn't feel awkwardly forced for unnecessarily meaningless drama to cover up the blatant puzzle-game focus which dominated the first season. The elements in the second season flow with harmony, complementing eachother, rather than competing with eachother.With improved graphics, style, scenery, and atmosphere, the settings and faces of the characters are much more realistic, and the game had a major improvement in production quality overall. Very polished.With improved controls and intuitive interaction with the settings, puzzles, and QTE's, there are no more annoying hicups from crappy design flaws, and NO MORE ambiguously written choices which end up doing the opposite of what you intended.The dialogue and reactions from the characters are MUCH more realistic and believable, and easier to connect to and be immersed with in the story.MAJOR improvements were made in the writting of the story, focusing on many heavy themes about life, death, trust, redemption, hope, and survival.I cried.

												On its own I can definitely recommend getting the second season of the 'Walking Dead'. You will be a little lost with out playing the first one though. The story is still really strong and compelling and will drive you to tears just as much as the last game, although the lack of any real choice might equally drive you to tears when you are on your third play through and its all the same. The game also looks and sounds just as good as the last game. But, the lack of any new technical updates might be viewed as a minus by some people. Like I told my friend, I rate this game ten out of ten, but I won't be buying again.If you want, you can find a more extended review here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2015/07/the-walking-dead-season-two.html.

Posted: January 29, 2015
												Ho...um, okay. So I had previously bought all the 1st season on xbox and intended to get S2 as well. I kept putting it off and off and off even when S2 finished and released on PC, it wasn't until the day I wrote this review that I bought both it AND S1. I've already completed S1 on xbox and I just played the first episode of S2. This game is something else let me tell you. There isn't any middle ground or any sort of "oh you didn't really decided anything, don't worry, it'll happen anyway". Every time you have to make a split second decision on this you feel the panic as if you were actually there and thats what truely captures that frightened, survivor feel. Without spoiling anything, imagine if you have to choose between going with one person and choosing another, its a panicked situation and you don't have time to plan out the decision so choose quickly and choose NOW. These make or break scenarios which are scattered both obviously and subtley are what makes this and any other similar telltale game a masterpiece. Its been beautiful watching Telltale become the powerhouse in game and story telling that they now are. I hope they keep making fantastic games.More important however, is that you buy this game, you will definetly not regret it.

												Following in the footsteps of the critically acclaimed First Season, Season 2 had a very difficult task to match the emotional intensity the previous game bestowed. It's debatable which game is more emotional (I'd say their on par), but Season 2 is undoubtedly more intense than ever before.Sequels in any form are difficult. Whether it be games, movies or TV shows , it will always be hard to match the original, especially if it is held in such a high regard. I feel Season 2 has suffered some unfair criticism because of it. Season 2 had to do be very different from the first, it couldn't fall into the trap of copying everything that Season 1 did so well, otherwise people would have complained. Since you changed it up a bit people have complained about certain things. No matter what Telltale did, it was impossible for  them to please everybody.Clementine throughout this series has become in my opinion, one of the most consistent, well developed characters I have ever seen. With the options we're presented it's up the player to choose how they wish to develop the character. You can try hold onto her innocence as long as possible, or you can fall under the darker nature of the story I'd absolutely recommend this game to anybody who enjoys a strong, emotional story. It has a very strong atmosphere, a great soundtrack and some unforgettable moments.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												WDS2 continues from S1 with Clementine escaping the chaos, continuing her journey with some familiar friends.  In the WD tradition things head south quickly and we begin the next chapter in this excellent interactive story.In terms of gameplay there have been a few small changes from S1, primarily in that the narrative and characters are getting more emphasis as I believe they should in this format.  There are no actual puzzles to solve here; however there are occasional moments of interaction and minor exploration.  There are some QTEs also, possibly more than the previous game, which succeed in creating tension.The big emphasis hewever is shaping Clementine through her frequent dialog choices.  Will she be cold and heartless?  Will she be reserved but empathetic?  Will she be courageous and pious?  There are many more dialog choices in this season, and the impact on the way other characters perceive Clementine is noticeable.  As with last season, your choices can impact who lives or dies... although in some situations you have no choice but to determine how Clementine deals with the death of a friend.As with S1 the general story progression is fixed but minor plot points and character relationships can be influenced by your actions and dialog.  You could replay the game and try some different choices but I suspect the outcome would not be very rewarding.Graphically the game feels a bit improved but only incrementally.  The animation seems a bit smoother and the facial expressions are also improved.  The style remains hand drawn cartoon-inspired which is appropriate.All in all I'm glad that Telltale decided to focus on the narrative and character development.  Rarely does a game invoke an emotional response like this one did.  I am looking forward to another season of this series and will snatch it up for sure.9/10

Posted: August 26, 2014
												Just like season 1, I laughed and I cried.. but the second season of this amazing series is unfortunately the weaker of the two, although still a masterpiece in it's own right. The stakes are higher, and while season 1 has you bond with Clementine on a personal level, season 2 directly puts you in her shoes, allowing you to mold and shape her character even further. This was a brilliant move for a variety of reasons, as given Clementine's age, she's physically far weaker than Lee was in season 1. Instead, she has to approach dangerous scenarious by being quick and clever in order to survive, making you feel more helpless than you did in S1. This changes things up a lot and I'm very happy with the direction Telltale took. Additionally, depending on the choices you make during the final episode, you have access to a variety of drastically different endings that from the looks of things, will give everyone a very different season 3, thus increasing the replayability.Well done Telltale.. you've done it again.

Posted: July 22, 2014
												While the overall story is still very gripping, I feel that there is very little actual choice when it comes down to it. While decisions in the first game would not always result in drastically different outcomes, it felt like there were sufficient real choices to make the game fun to play 5 times through and still leave avenues of choice unexplored. The second game was dull the second playthrough with far too many linear instances where once you know what is going to happen it becomes a very tedious trek from point A to point B with atmospheric effects that only worked the first time because you had no idea what would happen, but subsequent times felt like you were walking through a cheap haunted house yawning at the ghostly moans and twitching curtains. Aside from the lack of replayability, I found myself often wondering why tough guys who had apparently survived the hostile new zombie world thus far were suddenly putting their lives in the hands of a small girl they barely knew. While Lee in the first game was a capable, quick thinking young adult that I found was very easy to trust, it felt very wrong that the same trust was put in a small girl, who was often quite frightened herself. Yet if you enjoyed the first game, you don't care to play the game to death and you can see past the few thinly veiled plot tweaks designed to make our character the hero, then I would recommend this second season as good fun, intense and well drawn.

Posted: July 14, 2014
This is a review-in-progress; only episodes 1-3 are available as of this reviewOverallThe Walking Dead: Season 2 game, like its predecessor, is story driven game that is able to create the same sense of mystery, suspense, and action.  Improving on a lot of the systems, you have chances to mend broken relationships and create all new connections with new and old characters as you continue your story through the eyes of Clementine.ReviewThe Walking Dead: Season 2 continues a few months after the events in season 1 bringing together a whole new cast of characters with characters from its predecessor where new connections, relationships, and decisions will be formed.  Along with the new characters is a new perspective, where you once playing as an adult who had the strength to deal with the walkers head-on, you now play as Clementine, a young girl who has to use her wits in order to survive.  As with the predecessor, you are in control of your life, making various decisions for good or for bad to help mold Clementine into the character that you want her to be seen as; I feel as though the decisions have been changed for the better as they still impact you, but will not create as drastic of changes as to how each character views Clementine.  Although your decisions can change certain outcomes to an extent, you are generally tied to the story and will be limited in what can actually be changed.  Although the changes may be limited, the story is still full of mystery, suspense, and action to lead the player to want to know what comes next.Pros+ Unique story+ Improved decisions system+Connect with characters+ Point and click styleCons- Decisions cause limited impact towards the world- Episodic, can take a month or two for the next episode

Posted: August 29, 2014
												I enjoyed this just as much as season 1, except for the ending. I feel that season 1 had a much more impactful ending. Although Season 2 seems to have more available endings, only 1 or 2 really leave you feeling a sense of closure.One gripe I do have with season 2 is that it seems to provide even less choice to the player than season 1 did. It frequently gives the illusion that you are making an important decision but in the end, it doesn't actually matter (the same events occur regardless). In one instance, you have a chance to save a major character - if you do so, the character still ends up getting killed later in the episode anyway regardless of what you chose.However, the story and the characters are all still really incredibly interesting and well-written, as always. This is still yet another fantastic experience crafted by Telltale Games, and if you enjoyed Season 1 you really need to play this.

Posted: August 28, 2014
												My impression after Episode 1:Walking Dead Season 2 is phenomenal just like season 1 of the Walking Dead.Its literally a feels simulator. So much emotion in just a 1 hr and 30 min. I am so excited for the upcoming episodes based on how good the first episode is. Telltale games are expert storytellers.My impression after finishing Episode 5:Telltale does it again with a shocking finale to an excellent game. The choices you have to make are excruciating. By the end of the episode, you feel as if you truly lost some good friends. I rarely if never feel emotional after a game but this game is an exception. Telltale knows how to pull on your heartstrings. If you can make it thru the end without shedding a tear, you are not human. This game overall deserves a 10/10. Worth every penny and every second of your time. If you plan to only play one game this year, this along with Telltale game's other masterpiece Wolf Among Us should be on that short list. I can't wait to see how Telltale will try to one up this emotional roller coaster with season 3. This is easily a contender for best story of 2014 and dare I say GOTY. At this point, please do yourself a favor and just buy this game and play it through to the end.

												The Walking Dead Season 2 is a very soulful, realistic title, which introduces well-made game mechanics and thinking strategies, it always has you thinking each moment of the game, and puts you in the protagonist's place and state of mind. As for the characters, they sure do pack a punch, they are spirited, very well-animated and Telltale games sure did know how to make them. This is not just a videogame, it makes us think on what we would do, think, and act on real-time situations. And not to take every decision, day, or moment for granted.

Posted: January 24, 2016
												Spoiler/剧透预警行尸走肉第二章：Everyone  is ♥♥♥♥♥ or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ except Clem and Kenny. 最爱:Kenny无论kenney做错了什么，无论他的暴脾气如何，无论他如何怪异.在第一部里面，是他修好了船。第二部里面，是他修好了卡车。Kenney他其实就是游戏中的Rick. 这个顶天立地的男子汉，敢爱敢恨.第一部里面失去了老婆孩子，仍然坚强的活着. 第二部里面失去了新的爱人，情绪几近崩溃，最后还是去照顾那个孕妇(♥♥♥♥♥). 最后孕妇（♥♥♥♥♥）死了之后，kenney自然而然的承担起照顾孩子的责任. 最后Jane居然把孩子藏起来考验Kenney，Jane不明白人性经不起考验，这是多么stupid，所以最后她被kenney杀死，我觉得她罪有应得. 而Kenney，最后为了Clem和孩子，放弃自己进入营地，真是感天动地。果断选择和kenney一起。个人感觉是完美结局。Kenny作为一个男人，孤独的男人，他承担的太多，最后被几个♥♥♥♥♥，♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 各种judgement，如同Jane所说，那个什么狗Mike，俄国boy还有那个情妇背后议论kenney，你们几个垃圾有什么资格。屁都不会，Kenney干掉了黑帮头子，kenney是团队的支柱。下面开始判刑：最想他们死而不能死的：1.俄国boy，根本就是个脑残玩意。从clem跟他说，我是个孩子，能别用枪指着我吗。这狗比无动于衷。就知道这是个垃圾。于是，后面kenney几次要毙了他，垃圾团队不听，终于酿成大祸。2.Mike，这个叛徒。你放了俄国boy就算了，还他妈给他枪，这下好了，这狗比成了射击clem的帮凶。3.孕妇， 这就是个长舌妇，burden，以为自己坏了个不知道谁的种就可以成为中心了？大声叫引丧失，根本不关心clem的死活。最后她变丧失了，我就像rick一样，迫不及待给她脑袋来一枪，真是爽下面是喜爱但有致命缺点的：1.Luke，本来对luke很有好感的。但是他以为clem被咬了就把clem摔下来，从此路人。期间一直呛他，没帮他说过话。直到最后，冰里面他救了clem，才终于原谅了他。 LUKE其实是个挺矛盾的人，要怪只能怪他太年轻，老一点多一些担当和决断就更好了。2.Jane，一度很喜欢Jane，对clem很像一个大姐姐。但是她犯了致命错误，最后时刻她本可以不藏孩子。人性不能考验这是多年都说过了的。好人也可能上头干出出格的事，对我来说最后一件事就是一种挑衅。所以Jane你死的不冤，怪不了kenney。要怪怪你自己作死。3.情妇，就是400天里面打死别人老婆的。她给我的感觉就是weak，不能自己拿主意。最后和叛徒二人组出逃。在clem受伤以后才幡然醒悟。不想再说什么。

Posted: January 4, 2015
												I can't even remember a 'recent', single-player game that has hooked me in like this.The gameplay isn't its strong suit. Hell, it's barely more than a point-and-click.No. The strength is in the characters and the choices.The Walking Dead got its hooks into me within the first 15 minutes. Then, it wouldn't let me go until I was crying in the foetal position because of the choices I had made.It's pretty rare for a game to have characters that you genuinely care about, not just modern titles.The Walking Dead has the best characterisation I've seen for a long time. Clementine (and Lee from Season 1) is one of the most sympathetic characters out there.It's really tough to describe. It's something you have to experience first-hand.If you enjoy single-player experiences like I do, you're doing yourself a disservice by not buying The Walking Dead Seasons 1 and 2. Seriously.This gives me hope that not every single damn game that comes out from now will have ♥♥♥♥♥♥, tacked on multiplayer because that's 'all people want anymore'.10/10, will definitely play again.Christ, it's been a while since I rambled like that.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												NON-SPOILER REVIEWThe Walking Dead: Season 2 by TellTale Game's is a very much appreciated sequel to the riveting masterpiece that was Season 1. What is the fate of Christa and Omid? Your dearest Clem?Walking Dead Season 2 has a lot of similar aspects to Season 1, but with a better UI, graphics, and just about everything. Dialogue feels more fluid, and controlling Clementine is quite enjoyable, and you'd be surprised at her bravery. Overalll, Walking Dead Season 2 is a great sequel that left me wanting more. If you've never played Walking Dead, buy the first one, and if you enjoy that, definitely this!If you have played the first one and you liked it, you'll definitely like this.SPOILER REVIEWWalking Dead Season 2 opens up with Clem walking with a pregnant Christa and a still cheerful Omid. Omid tells you to clean up, and as your in a bathroom cleaning up, a scavenger walks in and steals your gun, threatening you. Omid comes in slowly, and as he approaches your assaliant, the door shuts making a loud noise. The scavenger turns around and promptly shoots Omid in the chest.Christa comes in and shoots the scavenger dead. Bestowed with dreadful grief.A year later, you and Christa are in a forest, and suddenly when Christa goes out to find wood, she becomes captured by bandits.This is the setup for Season 2, and it is as riveting as it is tearjerking. The story continues on, but I wish not to explain all its anomalies for they differ from your choices, as do all TellTale games...This Episode seemed to merely set up the plot, and I actually found myself missing the locales of Season 1. Hopefully though, maybe we can meet some old faces. Some possibilities are: Lily, Molly, and Kenny, supposing he survived the zombie attack, and because of what Clem(entine) says at the end of the Episode 2 teaser."I thought you were dead."9.75/10An overall great game.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												After completing the first episode of The Walking Dead: Season 2 these are my thoughts*roll cheap television intro with quite possibly 70's music*Okay, scratch the intro, lets talk about before I played the game. So when I first played the first episode of The Walking Dead: The Game, I was a bit skeptical, I'll be honest,  because it just didn't fully capture the vibe of the comics or the TV show, however, being the major TWD fanboy I am, I stuck with it, and my god am I glad I did! Everything about it was so perfectly done... okay well maybe not the interface... or all the glitches..and bugs...Well, my friends! I can safely say that The Walking Dead: Season 2, has changed up the Interface (for the better) and it is now bug-free (well it was in my playthrough at least)! When they announced Season 2 of this beloved cult icon videogame I so heavily adore, I also noticed that they had just been working on another game (The Wolf Among Us) and what's this..? they have just announced 2 more games.. Tales From the Borderlands and Game of Thrones games..? All while making TWD:S2, this got me a little worried that the story will drop off or that there will be a little less effort put into TWD:S2, Yet the good people of Telltale Games have made yet another hit, this game is gripping and it is intense and my god is it unforgiving, everything you loved about Lee is starting to shine through Clem, she is brave and she is strong and she is oh so tough. I'm not going to spoil anything but there is one point in this game which is in. your f**king face.it forces you to watch because if you dont, theres no getting through that section! I found myself shuddering with every action I had to make in that section so much so that I actually said to myself.. wait. its just a game and felt like a complete fool but I didnt care because it just reminded me of the sheer emotional and gut-wrenching power of Telltales writing and excecution of their gameplay! Now while we're on the topic of the writing of this game, I was also worried when I heard it was being written by different people, but wha-la! Another extensively incredible game from Telltale Games, the only complaint, which isn't even really a complaint, its more of a complaint im proud to say that I have, is that now i have to wait for the next bloody episode! Overall this game is already amazing, a very solid start (unlike season 1) to what looks to be another incredibly heart-stopping season, of The Walking Dead, and man, it feels good to be back.Would I reccommend it? Read the top of the review dumbass!9.8/10

Posted: May 3, 2014
												As I started the second season of TellTale's popular interactive storybook tale based on the popular AMC television series, I felt very deeply immersed in the story that was revolving around the protagonist. I was given tough choices and had a strong emotional response to every consequence.The continuation from Season One feels seemless now that I recall the events of the past, especially when I see the consequences of the choices in that game affecting the story in this sequel in meaningful ways. At first, the choices I made in Season Two didn't seem so meaningful, but it is slowly creeping up on me as I make progress and the plot begins to unfold. Even the smallest choices have the potential to twist the plot.However, I highly recommend not reading the names of the achievements in this game before returning to the zombie apocalypse. And I personally wouldn't find it enjoyable unless I completed Season One. I can't imagine not experiencing Season One and then even pretending that I understand the protagonist to Season Two.All of what matters to me personally aside, expect a lot of button context actions, dialogue options, and forshadowing that inevitably kicks you in the gut. I honestly don't know why TellTale bothered with so many achievements in an interactive storytelling game, but I can't help but look the other way because this story is told so well that I can't quite put it down. If this series were a physical "Choose Your Own Adventure" book, then I'd read it until I had to start taping pages back together.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												Well now that I finished all the available content (Up to season 2 episode 4), I have decided its time to write a very detailed review about what I can easly say became my favorite game series of all time.This review WILL contain minor spoilers (Major spoilers will contain a warning before they are written).I am going to review the series (Both games so far) assuming people reading this have already played the first game.Let's get started.This game is hard. Now when I say hard, I don't mean that it is overly complicated or difficult.... no this game is on a whole new level of "hard". The game does such an amazing job by playing with your emotions that you can't figure out if you are playing the game or it is playing you. I can't count how many times I found myself tearing up because of an event in the game.MINOR SPOILERS BEYOND THIS POINT!Season 1:In the first game of the series you play as a man named lee, an american history teacher who was on his way to jail for commiting a murder. As the story progresses you are faced with choices, choices you would never wanted to make if it was really you... With each episode the choices become harder as you find yourself getting on the better side of some people in your group and on the worse side of others.But choices arn't the only thing you need to warry about, you have a little 8 year old girl to take care of, named Clementine.You find this little girl about 5 miniuts into the game alone and scared hiding in her tree house in the back yard of her home.The little girl was waiting for her parents to come home from thier vacation when dead started walking the streets. At first Clemntine (I will call her Clem from now on) doesn't really trust you but that soon changes when she understands that  you are the only one who hasn't given up on her.As the game progresses you get to know a lot of people, some better some worse but who is your real friend is up to you to decide. Trusting people will be hard but you have to do what is best for Clem.By the end of the game you (The player) realize that the story didn't revolve around some guy named Lee the game is really about an 8 (by that time 9) year old girl named Clementine. You get to see her grow up, you teach her the basics of survival just to make sure she can live. You also get to see what a post apocalptic world does to a little Innocent girl as she turns from just some first grader you need to take care of to something better and stronger than any adult.MAJOR SPOILERS ABOUT SEASON 1 BEYOND THIS POINT!Season 2:In this installment you play as Clementine and you instantly see the change in her. She is no longer that innocent little girl you saw in the first game, she is now colder, smarter, stronger. The harsh post apocaliptic wasteland turn a sweat little girl into something else, something that might seem scary at first but as you go along the story, you understand that those changers are necessary for survival.Along the story Clem mentions Lee a few times and I couldn't just sit there. Every time she mentioned him I had to grab a tissue.Not all tears in this game are tears of sadness. At one part of the game, Clem is just the type of person that can sometimes bring tears of joy to your eyes even when things seem grim, there is always a moment of happynes. In conclution:This is a game for people who want a story. There is almost no gameplay involved but trust me, if the story seems even a little interesting it is well worth your money.This game is not for the weak of heart since it has a way of getting to you. (I rarely cry even in very sad movies but this game just got to me and I was crying like a little girl).This game might not have amazing graphics but it is not important, this game really is something special. Its a clear example of what's inside is what matters.This game is best played alone (since choices of people may very).10/10 WOULD AND WILL PLAY AGAIN

Posted: January 24, 2016
												Spoiler/剧透预警行尸走肉第二章：Everyone  is ♥♥♥♥♥ or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ except Clem and Kenny. 最爱:Kenny无论kenney做错了什么，无论他的暴脾气如何，无论他如何怪异.在第一部里面，是他修好了船。第二部里面，是他修好了卡车。Kenney他其实就是游戏中的Rick. 这个顶天立地的男子汉，敢爱敢恨.第一部里面失去了老婆孩子，仍然坚强的活着. 第二部里面失去了新的爱人，情绪几近崩溃，最后还是去照顾那个孕妇(♥♥♥♥♥). 最后孕妇（♥♥♥♥♥）死了之后，kenney自然而然的承担起照顾孩子的责任. 最后Jane居然把孩子藏起来考验Kenney，Jane不明白人性经不起考验，这是多么stupid，所以最后她被kenney杀死，我觉得她罪有应得. 而Kenney，最后为了Clem和孩子，放弃自己进入营地，真是感天动地。果断选择和kenney一起。个人感觉是完美结局。Kenny作为一个男人，孤独的男人，他承担的太多，最后被几个♥♥♥♥♥，♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 各种judgement，如同Jane所说，那个什么狗Mike，俄国boy还有那个情妇背后议论kenney，你们几个垃圾有什么资格。屁都不会，Kenney干掉了黑帮头子，kenney是团队的支柱。下面开始判刑：最想他们死而不能死的：1.俄国boy，根本就是个脑残玩意。从clem跟他说，我是个孩子，能别用枪指着我吗。这狗比无动于衷。就知道这是个垃圾。于是，后面kenney几次要毙了他，垃圾团队不听，终于酿成大祸。2.Mike，这个叛徒。你放了俄国boy就算了，还他妈给他枪，这下好了，这狗比成了射击clem的帮凶。3.孕妇， 这就是个长舌妇，burden，以为自己坏了个不知道谁的种就可以成为中心了？大声叫引丧失，根本不关心clem的死活。最后她变丧失了，我就像rick一样，迫不及待给她脑袋来一枪，真是爽下面是喜爱但有致命缺点的：1.Luke，本来对luke很有好感的。但是他以为clem被咬了就把clem摔下来，从此路人。期间一直呛他，没帮他说过话。直到最后，冰里面他救了clem，才终于原谅了他。 LUKE其实是个挺矛盾的人，要怪只能怪他太年轻，老一点多一些担当和决断就更好了。2.Jane，一度很喜欢Jane，对clem很像一个大姐姐。但是她犯了致命错误，最后时刻她本可以不藏孩子。人性不能考验这是多年都说过了的。好人也可能上头干出出格的事，对我来说最后一件事就是一种挑衅。所以Jane你死的不冤，怪不了kenney。要怪怪你自己作死。3.情妇，就是400天里面打死别人老婆的。她给我的感觉就是weak，不能自己拿主意。最后和叛徒二人组出逃。在clem受伤以后才幡然醒悟。不想再说什么。

Posted: October 23, 2015
												Summary: Deus ex zombinaMultiplayer: NoCompletion: 11 hrsCards: NoCloud: YesThe Walking Dead Season 2 picks up right after where Season 1 leaves off. Clem, now living with Omid and Christa, set off to survive on their own. While it is much advised to play Season 1 first, you can enjoy Season 2 without having played Season 1 prior. There will be some story elements spoiled in doing so. I'm pretty bummed you can't skip dialog in this game. I wanted to replay the whole game, but this alone made me think otherwise. Adding to that is the fact that you cannot skip credits either. Considering you'll see the credits five times in a playthrough, this decision makes no sense whatsoever. And you still cannot save/load your games at will. It's like the game conspires against you trying to replay.The sound and graphics are pretty much the same quality as the first game. The quality of writing may have gone down a bit, as many options they provide are less thoughtful this time around. Characters change attititudes over small things, and some characters are outright useless. That said, it's still an enjoyable read, and certainly enough to keep your interest to the end.I give Season 2 of The Walking Dead a 8.5/10. It flows at a nice brisk (albeit liner) pace, and does a good job keeping you entertained to the end. My main criticisms are outlined below in the spoiler section.***SPOILER SECTION***I have a theory that Telltale games supports the Novikov self-consistency principle. This idea states that any changes a time traveler makes is history all along. Thus the past cannot be changed, and attempts to change it would result in an event to ensure consistency. Try replaying any chapter and select new choices. Same outcome, right? Unfortunately, because I was aware of my inability to actually influence the story, it removed much of the immersion and I stopped caring about what I picked. Every time I saw "[This person] will remember that", I saw it as a death sentence. What was the point in remembering your choices when the NPC is going to die a few scenes later? What was the point in being a good samaritan if you are going to be attacked anyway? Why should I save anyone at all? I mean I'll still do it, but I already know it's pointless. I get that they want to create the illusion of crafting your own story by presenting timed responses, but it's obvious nothing matters. While I appreciate Telltale for trying to tell a solid story, I had trouble suspending my disbelief when most of the remaining humans have have become crazy, corrupt, and/or traitorous. Those that aren't are promptly killed off or slowly corrupted. Why is it always man vs man anyway? No one tries to go on the offensive to cure the zombieism any more. Even if there's no cure in the end, it's something that people should never stop pursuing.There's a consistent pattern that goes on in the entire Walking Dead universe. Main character finds a (usually friendly but not always) group . Group starts to fall apart. Deus ex zombina. People die. Move to new location. Repeat ad infinitum. The "move to new location" part I find amusing because whenever someone mentions "settling" it always ends bad and they must move. And I'm pretty sure this is because staying in one location would be boring to watch, play or read. If this were real of course people would like to settle. But that would simply be boring to write about and experience. The chart showing your responses compared to other players is interesting, but flawed. A number of decisions are virtually no-brainers. Why would I not climb in the ticket booth when it looks and sounds empty? Decisions that sound dangerous to Clem don't work because we know as players the game will not kill you for it. Typically the only way to die is to fail at a quicktime event. The good decisions have two seemingly good outcomes, or are hard to figure out the lesser of two evils. For example, the option to rob Arvo was a good choice, since you could certainly use the meds. Instead most choices are to be nice or mean. At the very least, if we're given mean choices, I'd like to be a bad♥♥♥♥♥doing it. For example a choice between saving the baby or shooting the Ruskies. You bet I'd shoot Arvo if given the chance (though I'm sure they'll try to spin some tale to make him sympathetic next season). One choice I wish I picked differently was chopping off Sarita's arm, because chopping it off was definitely a bad idea. Of course she'd scream and alert the whole mob if you did that, but I didn't have enough time to think it through. It still doesn't matter, but the option and urgency here was good. While a majority of decisions do not matter, surprisingly you can make an actual fork in the game at the end. I did appreciate this a lot. However, I'm fairly certain the fork will converge right away when Season 3 rolls out.Walking Dead Season 2 is still a good game, I just wish we could make an appreciable difference in the story and the world.

Review for The Walking Dead: Season 2 Pros:Graphic style: Is very well made, it feels nice and is very enjoyable, The Walking Dead universe with it is made very well, world is shown as it should be in The Walking Dead.Choices: Every choice is hard even the smallest one because everyone will remember it, you control the lives of other by helping them or dooming them. Every choice feels heavy and is hard to choose, there is no better way or best choice with which everyone will be happy and survive. Most choices feels like made under pressure because of little time you are given to choose but that's what makes them feel realistic because you regret what you did.World: Is very well made, it feels destroyed, dangerous and horrible. Atmosphere: One of the best things of the game, every thing feels realistic, you feel guilt because of you actions, world is going down and becoming more dangerous every day because Walkers grow in number while humans are becoming less by each day.Story: Very well written, characters feel alive, they are angry, they have emotions, they have regrets. Story itself is hearthbraking as little girl sruggles to survive in a wretched world and every her choice decides the fate of others.Replay value: It has huge replay value because choices change the story and outcome of it, so it can be replayed several times over.Cons:To me there was none, i liked the game from start to end, didn't had any techinal issues with game or other problems.Summary: I recommend the game for everyone who loves games with great storys, heavy choices and to those who like games which have a lot of emotions (may make you sad, happy or even let a tear out).9/10

Posted: August 27, 2014
												As a fan of the first season, I was not sure what would be in store for the second. This was mainly due to the change of protagonist from the first season from being a likable confident character to a slightly skittish child. My doubts, however, were put to rest and I can confidently say that Telltale has done an excellent job once more. They have created a story which continues to engage the player and challenge their sense of morality when faced with choices and decisions. While some chapters were better than others, each chapter left me satisfied. Clementine, the main protagonist, develops throughout the game around the members of her group, most of which influence her one way or another. I'm happy to see that Telltale has allowed the player to decide how Clem reacts and which people she wants to befriend. The final chapter sees the toughest choices being made, all which will tug on the player's loyalties and emotions.New players to the Telltale Walking Dead games, I couldn't recommend it more to start with season one. You will miss out a lot of character back story and, with it, part of the richness the series has to offer. In fact, reflecting on my experience and the references back to season one, it's vital.Continuing players from season one, if you loved the story and the game, you won't be disappointed with this instalment.

												I can't even remember a 'recent', single-player game that has hooked me in like this.The gameplay isn't its strong suit. Hell, it's barely more than a point-and-click.No. The strength is in the characters and the choices.The Walking Dead got its hooks into me within the first 15 minutes. Then, it wouldn't let me go until I was crying in the foetal position because of the choices I had made.It's pretty rare for a game to have characters that you genuinely care about, not just modern titles.The Walking Dead has the best characterisation I've seen for a long time. Clementine (and Lee from Season 1) is one of the most sympathetic characters out there.It's really tough to describe. It's something you have to experience first-hand.If you enjoy single-player experiences like I do, you're doing yourself a disservice by not buying The Walking Dead Seasons 1 and 2. Seriously.This gives me hope that not every single damn game that comes out from now will have ♥♥♥♥♥♥, tacked on multiplayer because that's 'all people want anymore'.10/10, will definitely play again.Christ, it's been a while since I rambled like that.

Posted: December 24, 2014
												Zombie fiction in general, but especially this season of Telltale’s The Walking Dead often beg the question: do you have to be stupid to survive the zombie apocalypse or does surviving the zombie apocalypse just make you stupid?I thought season one of Telltale’s The Walking Dead was filled with morons, but it can’t hold a candle to season two’s cast of self-centered, bickering, half-wits. Having played the first episode back when it was originally released, I jumped back into the shoes of Clementine to tackle the Zombie ridden mid-Atlantic yet again. Feeling much more formulaic than the first season and dragging a bit due in part to their attempt to create their own “Governor” character in the first three episodes, The Walking Dead Season Two didn’t quite have the punch of the first especially when it became obvious that any decision I made was going to be “wrong” in some way. Toward the end I decided that the game was no longer about survival or choosing the correct path. With the plethora of idiots and disappointment I was being faced with, I decided that my ultimate goal was to make sure that Clem didn’t end up as stupid and overall awful as these people.All told, despite its uber dismal tone, The Walking Dead Season Two was still entertaining, enjoyable, and well made. After having played The Wolf Among Us however I did find myself missing certain quality-of-life features like not having to press “E” after mashing “Q” during quick time events, or being able to easily see and understand quick time directional cues. Even the credits are friendlier in The Wolf Among Us, because I can skip them, a nice feature to have when you’replaying episodes back to back. The Walking Dead Season Two doesn’t even allow you to escape to the main menu during its credits. All that aside, I’m looking forward to season three and hoping that Clem can find some decent people to hang out with this time around.

Posted: January 29, 2015
												The follow up to the critically acclaimed Walking Dead season 1 game by Telltale, Season 2 keeps you incredibly invested in its story and characters.You can see my review of season 1 for the usual details, but essentially it's the same old Telltale gameplay. The game is more like an interactive story, focusing more on storytelling rather than moment-to-moment action. Thus, this game is not for you if you're looking for the next innovative, fast-paced, gameplay. If you're looking for a strong story that may or may not leave you emotionally devastated, this is for you.Like the first game, the gameplay is more of a classic "point and click" adventure style game. Throughout the game you'll be able to move around in a very limited area and investigate points of interest by highlighting them with the cursor and using a few different action keys. There are also plenty of quick time events, although unlike other games they feel..."right" for the genre rather than out of place and annoying. The gameplay is nothing to be excited about - instead, it is a means of interaction, allowing you as a player to move the story along and make key decisions.Again however, the story is what you're here for. Season 2 picks up after the events of Season 1 and its small DLC, 400 Days. You have the option of importing decisions you made in the first game over to new games in Season 2, although this is not necessary (but I recommend it nonetheless of course). You play as Clementine this time, one of the primary characters from Season 1. The gameplay/story differs a bit because unlike last time, you are now a little girl in a zombie apocalypse. Characters amy underestimate you or treat you differently due to the large age difference, along with giving you as a player a fairly different perspective when it comes to making decisions and interacting with characters.Other minor details is the appreciated addition of a "move faster" button that you can hold down, so that plodding nature of your character doesn't slow things down too much. In addition, the artwork and graphics seems to have improved compared to Season 1, and there is a greater variety of environments and colours used.For those who played through Season 1, Season 2 is definitely worth getting. Aside from continuing the story and potentially crying some more, Season 2 doesn't feel any weaker and continues to hold up Telltale's golden storytelling standards.If you haven't played any of the Telltale Walking Dead games (or many of their other games for that matter, such as Wolf Among Us), I highly recommend this series if you're at all interested in good story and don't mind a much simpler gameplay.

Posted: August 30, 2014
												Season Two of the Walking Dead is another masterpiece in storytelling from Telltale, a developer who are quickly becoming one of my favourites thanks to this franchise and Wolf Among Us. I'm not sure if there's another developer out there on such a hot streak right now.In season two the player controls Clementine. At first I wasn't sure if this was a good idea. My interactions with her were the best parts of season one, especially seeing how she reacted to and learned from my decisions, and I was worried that her personality might be spoiled. However, I quickly found that it presented an interesting roleplaying opportunity that influenced the way I interacted with other characters. Being younger means not having a leadership role, and trying to be more persuasive rather than just taking charge. Meanwhile being physically weaker meant I had more respect for the bad guys' strength, and situations where I might have just attacked immediately in season one as Lee, I found myself being a lot more cautious.Along the way you'll meet lots of new characters as well as a couple of familiar faces. The dialogue is well written and voice acting is excellent. You'll encounter various threats from both the living and the dead, which result in some very tough choices. Most scenarios don't have an obvious best answer, and many consequences are unpredictable. You're just trying to do whatever it takes to keep everyone alive as you stumble from one bad situation to the next.The core gameplay mechanics remain intact. Most of the time you'll be making dialogue choices, many of which will influence the story in some way. Compared to season one there are less sections where you need to walk around and find objects to solve puzzles. I think this is probably the main reason why the episodes are shorter. I finished season 2 in 8 hours compared to 11 hours for season 1. Combat sections are again controlled by QTEs but they are relatively painless. I think there was only one section where I died multiple times. I didn't experience any bugs or crashes.My only real disappointment is the lack of effect carried through from my season one choices. There was a line of dialogue here and there, but nothing really significant.I highly recommend playing the Walking Dead. If you enjoyed season one, there is no reason to think you would be disappointed by season two.

Posted: July 4, 2014
												The long awaited sequel to the acclaimed Telltale adventure, The Walking Dead: Season 2 offers just as much excitement and emotion as its predecessor. The game now allows players to take the role of the beloved Clementine, whom we saw abandoned at the close of Season 1. Clem is now older and more hardened to her cruel apocalypse life. Players quickly meet new characters (friends and foes) that have many mysteries behind them. Though at first it is hard to accept those that feel like replacements for our lost allies of the first game, after Episode 1, I found I had warmed up to this interesting bunch. The new threat of a captivating villain known as Carver paralells events which have occured throughout the universe before. Although it seems like a repeat of the "evil group" trope we've come to know, this plot line (without giving away too much) has some twists. Many moments throughout bring heartache, tension, and moral conflicts the likes of which are not often given in video games. The final scene of the newest episode, In Harm's Way, is one of the most thrilling and hard-hitting gaming experiences I have ever had, causing my heart rate to rise and sticking with me for hours after (but again, no spoilers). Aside from some minor graphics errors (ie. objects phasing through each other) here and there, Season 2 has shown a great improvement. The controls are much easier to handle, allowing for better sensitity and a more user-friendly "choices" interface. The game also implements new actions, mostly involving the use of the arrow keys for dodging and loosening items. Overall, this game is a must have. I am very excited for the next installment, and hope that the story of Season 2 rounds of as amazingly as I expect it will.

Posted: August 30, 2014
												Just a comment from pcgamers i saw, and it's all i want say, all my choice:"I feel completely the opposite way. Seeing how Kenny reacted, I knew that he had to go. Kenny had become the kind of person that you just really can't be around. I get that Kenny would never hurt Clem, but he so easily could snap at others, just as he did Jane. I mean, I left her too. As much as I liked her, she was no better for tricking both Clem and Kenny. But Kenny had become something of a monster. Maybe monster is a harsh word, but he was a time bomb, as Jane said, waiting to explode. I think that the happy-ish ending robs the story of something very important, and that is the final lesson that Clem had to learn.A lot of what this season was about, to me, was Clem becoming a survivor, preparing to face choices alone. In season 1, we, as Lee, became her guardian and that was all about Lee taking care of her. She became the center of the story because it was a story that was no longer about personal survival, it was about the survival of innocence, which is what Clem was. This season was all about Clem learning how to survive on her own, learning what choices to make, not just in terms of basic survival skills but in terms of making the best choices when it comes to dealing with people. I'm sorry, but Kenny dying was almost a necessity by the end. He was simply too unstable and too unpredictable. Chances are Kenny would have eventually gotten himself, and even Clem, killed. I do admit that in the other ending, where Kenny sacrifices his own safety for Clem and A.J.'s, that was a noble thing to do. And it seems true to his loyalty to Clem. But I feel like it robs Clem of the hardest lesson she had to learn in the game: what do you do when people have gone overboard? Once someone has gone so far over the edge they can't come back, what do you do?The 'happier' ending tells us that Kenny will be able to fight through it, but I very highly doubt this. With all that he has lost and his obvious displays of rage and anguish, I do not believe that Kenny would ever recover. While his sacrifice is noble, he is still out of his mind and can't be saved as far as I am concerned. And I think that Clem needed to learn this. It's the primary reason I killed him. To me, this is the completion to this season for Clem specifically. Of all the lessons, it's the hardest one to learn, but it had to be learned."

It frequently gives the illusion that you are making an important decision but in the end, it doesn't actually matter (the same events occur regardless). In one instance, you have a chance to save a major character - if you do so, the character still ends up getting killed later in the episode anyway regardless of what you chose.However, the story and the characters are all still really incredibly interesting and well-written, as always. Posted: August 22, 2014
												Well now that I finished all the available content (Up to season 2 episode 4), I have decided its time to write a very detailed review about what I can easly say became my favorite game series of all time.This review WILL contain minor spoilers (Major spoilers will contain a warning before they are written).I am going to review the series (Both games so far) assuming people reading this have already played the first game.Let's get started.This game is hard. Now when I say hard, I don't mean that it is overly complicated or difficult.... no this game is on a whole new level of "hard". The game does such an amazing job by playing with your emotions that you can't figure out if you are playing the game or it is playing you. I can't count how many times I found myself tearing up because of an event in the game.MINOR SPOILERS BEYOND THIS POINT!Season 1:In the first game of the series you play as a man named lee, an american history teacher who was on his way to jail for commiting a murder. As the story progresses you are faced with choices, choices you would never wanted to make if it was really you... With each episode the choices become harder as you find yourself getting on the better side of some people in your group and on the worse side of others.But choices arn't the only thing you need to warry about, you have a little 8 year old girl to take care of, named Clementine.You find this little girl about 5 miniuts into the game alone and scared hiding in her tree house in the back yard of her home.The little girl was waiting for her parents to come home from thier vacation when dead started walking the streets. At first Clemntine (I will call her Clem from now on) doesn't really trust you but that soon changes when she understands that  you are the only one who hasn't given up on her.As the game progresses you get to know a lot of people, some better some worse but who is your real friend is up to you to decide. Trusting people will be hard but you have to do what is best for Clem.By the end of the game you (The player) realize that the story didn't revolve around some guy named Lee the game is really about an 8 (by that time 9) year old girl named Clementine. You get to see her grow up, you teach her the basics of survival just to make sure she can live. You also get to see what a post apocalptic world does to a little Innocent girl as she turns from just some first grader you need to take care of to something better and stronger than any adult.MAJOR SPOILERS ABOUT SEASON 1 BEYOND THIS POINT!Season 2:In this installment you play as Clementine and you instantly see the change in her. She is no longer that innocent little girl you saw in the first game, she is now colder, smarter, stronger. The harsh post apocaliptic wasteland turn a sweat little girl into something else, something that might seem scary at first but as you go along the story, you understand that those changers are necessary for survival.Along the story Clem mentions Lee a few times and I couldn't just sit there. Every time she mentioned him I had to grab a tissue.Not all tears in this game are tears of sadness. At one part of the game, Clem is just the type of person that can sometimes bring tears of joy to your eyes even when things seem grim, there is always a moment of happynes. In conclution:This is a game for people who want a story. There is almost no gameplay involved but trust me, if the story seems even a little interesting it is well worth your money.This game is not for the weak of heart since it has a way of getting to you. (I rarely cry even in very sad movies but this game just got to me and I was crying like a little girl).This game might not have amazing graphics but it is not important, this game really is something special. Its a clear example of what's inside is what matters.This game is best played alone (since choices of people may very).10/10 WOULD AND WILL PLAY AGAIN

Posted: December 31, 2014
												Play this game.The only people I can see not enjoying the Walking Dead: Season Two are those who fall into the following categories: people who didn't play the first one; people who don't like story-driven games; people who are turned off by graphic violence and/or overly affected by emotional storylines; people who are absolutely revolted by the concept of the zombie horror subgenre; and racists.  That last one was a joke, but seriously, if you're racist, stay away.  There are minorities everywhere.I finished Season Two about an hour ago, and I am reeling.  For fans of the first game who worried that the formula would be stale in the second one: fear not.  One or two plot points are easily predicted, but there are more than enough surprises here to keep the momentum going.  Even at its absolute dullest, the Walking Dead: Season Two is tense, dark and powerfully compelling.  At its best, the game is -- dare I say it? -- beautiful.Season Two wastes absolutely no time punching you in the balls (figuratively), and slowly builds to a brutal and haunting finale that will have you instantly asking, "What's next?"  If you weren't hooked after the first one, you will be after this.Some reviewers and forum posters are careless about spoilers, so be very careful.  You won't need a walkthrough, so don't worry about anything like that.  Just play, and enjoy having your heart ripped out all over again.

Posted: August 28, 2014
												The first game was brilliant, this game is even better. Watch how the little girl you raised as Lee in the first game survives without Lee and in most situations by herself. She seems to have learend this kind of leadership aspect from Lee so her decisions make a huge impact on what happens. This game brings so many emotions, terror, disgust, joy, helplessness and of course, sadness. There are moments in the game that can be heartwarming and other moments that can make you cry tears. For a "Point & Click" adventure it also has a nice pacing of action, any given moment a Zombie or even a full horde may appears, ruining your day by someone getting bit, decisions have to be made in these situation, the outcome can change how the game progresses. The Walking Dead Season 1 was already like that and it was brilliant, Season 2 just stays in this and it is STILL an amazing experience. This means it also got replay value, make another decision next time, see what happens. The story and character development, the good and the bad is truely amazing too. I don't want to spoil anything but a certain character appears you are just glad to see, and then you see him fall apart emotionally and getting angrier and angrier.Overall, this game is absolutely worth every single cent, if another game is gonna be made, I will definetly buy that too. I loved seeing Clem growing up and now fighting for herself and I would like to see more of that.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												While not a total let down, Telltale knows that very little will top the first season. So with that in mind, I think the whole season is actually pretty good. I was entertained mostly and while the episodes are short, who really wants them to drag it out? It was a quick and to the point aftermath of Season 1, and the ending (No Spoilers) was a good one, never going to top the original, but they knew that and gave us something a little different this time. I just wish that there was more choice/consequence variety in the series. While you would expect Season 2 to have a little more, it doesn't. I'd say it's worth a play if you enjoyed Season 1 and want to see the aftermath. Direct and to the point. A good game and I'd give it 7.5/10 for a good effort at following up the first.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												Just like season 1, I laughed and I cried.. but the second season of this amazing series is unfortunately the weaker of the two, although still a masterpiece in it's own right. The stakes are higher, and while season 1 has you bond with Clementine on a personal level, season 2 directly puts you in her shoes, allowing you to mold and shape her character even further. This was a brilliant move for a variety of reasons, as given Clementine's age, she's physically far weaker than Lee was in season 1. Instead, she has to approach dangerous scenarious by being quick and clever in order to survive, making you feel more helpless than you did in S1. This changes things up a lot and I'm very happy with the direction Telltale took. Additionally, depending on the choices you make during the final episode, you have access to a variety of drastically different endings that from the looks of things, will give everyone a very different season 3, thus increasing the replayability.Well done Telltale.. you've done it again.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												Here's my piece: I'M NOT BUYING ANYMORE EPISODIC TELL TALE GAMES.+Waiting a month inbetween each chapter always makes me confused as to what happened during my last playthrough.  Since there's so much time inbetween each episode, I'll often replay the chapter using different choices such that after a month I have no idea which playthrough I'm experiencing.+The entire (completed) game goes on sale for 60% on steam the same day the final chapter is realeased.   Really?  So I could buy chapter 1 for $24 or chapters 1-5 for $9 and finish the game at the same time?  Just... what?It's a really great game being sold by a great company in a terrible format.  I would have gladly waited the year or two to play the entire thing in settings chosen on my leisure.  I loved the game, but I feel like I can only recommend future Tell Tale Episodic adventures once the completed packaged is released.  Other than that, I'm actually quite a happy customer.

												Following in the footsteps of the critically acclaimed First Season, Season 2 had a very difficult task to match the emotional intensity the previous game bestowed. It's debatable which game is more emotional (I'd say their on par), but Season 2 is undoubtedly more intense than ever before.Sequels in any form are difficult. Whether it be games, movies or TV shows , it will always be hard to match the original, especially if it is held in such a high regard. I feel Season 2 has suffered some unfair criticism because of it. Season 2 had to do be very different from the first, it couldn't fall into the trap of copying everything that Season 1 did so well, otherwise people would have complained. Since you changed it up a bit people have complained about certain things. No matter what Telltale did, it was impossible for  them to please everybody.Clementine throughout this series has become in my opinion, one of the most consistent, well developed characters I have ever seen. With the options we're presented it's up the player to choose how they wish to develop the character. You can try hold onto her innocence as long as possible, or you can fall under the darker nature of the story I'd absolutely recommend this game to anybody who enjoys a strong, emotional story. It has a very strong atmosphere, a great soundtrack and some unforgettable moments.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												WDS2 continues from S1 with Clementine escaping the chaos, continuing her journey with some familiar friends.  In the WD tradition things head south quickly and we begin the next chapter in this excellent interactive story.In terms of gameplay there have been a few small changes from S1, primarily in that the narrative and characters are getting more emphasis as I believe they should in this format.  There are no actual puzzles to solve here; however there are occasional moments of interaction and minor exploration.  There are some QTEs also, possibly more than the previous game, which succeed in creating tension.The big emphasis hewever is shaping Clementine through her frequent dialog choices.  Will she be cold and heartless?  Will she be reserved but empathetic?  Will she be courageous and pious?  There are many more dialog choices in this season, and the impact on the way other characters perceive Clementine is noticeable.  As with last season, your choices can impact who lives or dies... although in some situations you have no choice but to determine how Clementine deals with the death of a friend.As with S1 the general story progression is fixed but minor plot points and character relationships can be influenced by your actions and dialog.  You could replay the game and try some different choices but I suspect the outcome would not be very rewarding.Graphically the game feels a bit improved but only incrementally.  The animation seems a bit smoother and the facial expressions are also improved.  The style remains hand drawn cartoon-inspired which is appropriate.All in all I'm glad that Telltale decided to focus on the narrative and character development.  Rarely does a game invoke an emotional response like this one did.  I am looking forward to another season of this series and will snatch it up for sure.9/10

Posted: December 19, 2014
												I loved the first Season and wrote a rave review about it and got the second season right away for more. I did have a good time with it, but I felt it drags on a little too much (which is weird, because it takes much less time to complete than Season 1) and the things that made the first season so great weren't in it for me. Clementine is an awesome protagonist and contributed a lot to the joy of Season 1, and she is just as important here and a real badass. However, they decided to make her like this freakishly wise kid that every adult has to come to for advice... I understand the gameplay reason, and sometimes I really enjoyed it for the reason that Clem really is forced to grow up, but it felt a bit off at times. They could've dialed back on it a little. I also didn't get to establish any bond between any of the other characters. The gang in Season 1 was a lot more interesting and their fates often came as a surprise or a sad feeling, while here I couldn't establish any bonds and their fates fell flat for me. There is still plenty of awesome in this season 2 and it's somewhat worthwhile - as long as you don't expect the same brilliant writing and reduce your expectations on the story. Since Steam doesn't support a Mixed Rating I give it a reluctant recommendation. I wonder how Season 3 will be... I fear for the worst, there is no way they can go with Clementine again and I just don't see how they can keep it fresh even with a all new cast after I played this. We'll see.

Posted: August 27, 2014
												The story of season 2 of Telltale Games' The Walking Dead is a bit more intense than the first and as it progresses it's very interesting to see how the influence of other characters as well as your dialogue choices force Clementine to shed her innocent little girl personality and basically turn her into a hardened survivor of the zombie apocolypse. Which is a good thing considering some of the grisly deaths you might meet. Speaking of which, don't expect the death scenes in S2 to be any less gruesome than those in S1 just because it now stars an 11-year old girl. Just like in S1 the nailbiting moments are there, the heart-wrenching moments are there, as well as the occassional WTF?! moment. One issue I have with season 2 is that the story didn't grip me as much as the first. And I think that's mainly because there's too much happening too fast. You rarely get a moment of reprieve in which you can really see some character development of the supporting cast, although it does make it all the more enjoyable when you do get one. That said it's still a great story with Clem being an excellent protagonist. If you played the first one and liked it, chances are you'll like this one. Fingers crossed for a Season 3!

Posted: November 12, 2015
												To start, I think that TellTale did an even better job on this game than they did for the first game in the Walking Dead series, and that original one was incredible. In season 2, you get to play as the little Clementine (I was so happy for this!), who really isn't so little anymore. She has grown since the first game, and I feel proud, like a mother. But this game is more than just the protagonist.I fell in love with the story. It made me so inspired as a writer. There were pieces thrown out throughout the episodes that made me cry out, pull at my hair, and simple shout "what!?". I think there is no dull moment in this game. It is nitty, gritty, sad, sweet, sentimental, and even romantic (why I think that, I don't know). It even made me think, if the zombie apocolypse really did happen, would I survive? And if I was able to ponder that question, I think TellTale did their job wonderfuly.The only thing I wished was possible in this game was a difference in the outcomes of the choices matter. I wish that there were certain actions in the game that could save a certain character's life. I think TellTale should think about that for the third season of The Walking Dead. 9/10.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												(This is mostly a copy/paste from my review for Season 1 as not much changes.)Overall pretty good. The game has a few down points but all in all I would give it 70/100 (50 is average). The game basically follows a group of people surviving the Zpocolypse like the show. It plays as an interactive story and the player makes choices for the main character. There isn't any gameplay really it is just point and click for I would say 75% of the game. The rest are small real time button mashes that you have to do, which are really kinda pointless in my opinion. The good thing about the game is that zombies are actually a pretty big part of the game unlike many "zombie" genre media that turns into nothing but soap operahs with a few zombies in the background as plot motivators. A qucik look around the internet and you will find that people get pretty emotionally invovled in this game, so thats always a good sign. For me, it wasn't as engaging but still well worth the time to go through it. Hard to say much else without spoiling the game for those who haven't played it.For the not-so-good. I think the most fusterating part of the game is the controls. They are very loose and don't always work. The control scheme can be annoyingly difficult to manipulate at times. This is slightly better in Season 2 but the changes that were made to the HUD I feel were not nessicarily better, just different. There still were a few times where I died simply becuase the controls did not get recognized in time.The other major issue was as with almost all choice based games there are often times when my personal choice just wasn't an option. You get 2 or maybe 3 choices and none of them are what I considered good so your left with just picking the least bad. That kinda kicks you out of the emersion a bit. This is particularly evident in Season 2 and it's ending. Probably from about Episode 4 and on I wasn't really on board with what was going on but there really is no option for what I would have done and that was pretty dissapointing. There are 5 different endings and while they all wrap up pretty decently, for me it felt like just watching a show I had no control over as the choices had to be made because the ones I would have done where simply not in the game. I was just going through iot to finish it after that point. That isn't to say the story is bad, it is pretty good, but not as an "interative" game that claims to be based on your own choices. Some other critique I have is mostly in the way of graphics. Overall it is a good style and the game looks good, but there are gliches here and there and the animations are sometimes wonky. Nothing game breaking or really bad but a lack of polish nontheless. This is much improved in Season 2. The game looks and feels a lot better in the animation department. Although I would also have to say that running into invisible walls was much more apparent in Season 2 as well which was very annoying at times and for the most part fairly pointless.So overall worth it. If you like this sort of game it is definitely worth picking up. If on the fence, it is worth picking up on a steam sale. I played it straight through and I guess steam didn't calculate all my time playing, but I think it was a little shorter than Season 1 @ about 10 - 12 hours total seems about right.

												Up until the end of Episode 4, I was really, really loving this game, but it turns out a huge choice you made earlier on (I'll put a spoiler tag at the end of this review) has absolutely no effect on the story and your character doesn't have any say in the matter. It's incredibly frustrating. I still recommend you play it, but that one ♥♥♥♥ up is just too big to ignore.Spoilers: At a certain point, you come across this Russian kid named Arvo, and you're given the choice to either steal his bag of supplies or send him on his way... Turns out that was completely pointless, as he accuses you of stealing the stuff regardless of your choices, and what's worse, there's not a single dialogue option you can choose saying that he's lying or that you didn't steal anything... You just have to stand there and admit it. It's like that choice didn't matter AT ALL and the outcome is the exact same, which is ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to say the least.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												Suspenseful and powerful; Season 2 of The Walking Dead picks up just after season 1 with tougher choices, more drama and a more streamlined interface.  Clementine is now the main character, using what she's learned in season 1 you go through 5 tense episodes that is full of some of the best written dialogue in video games, and make choices on who lives or who dies.  Although all your choices arent black and white, nor are they actually effective - when you're playing through it for the first time you will curse youself for anything you do wrong and will want to playthrough it again to see an alternate take.  With five different endings it will be very interesting where season 3 goes.  Very very recommended.As a season I give this a 5/5

												In my opinion it's vital to play the first season first, otherwise it could come as quite boring because of the emotional detachment to the characters.I've finished the full game twice. The second time I took the opossite choices each time and I have to say that not much has changed. So, as in the first season, choices don't alter the events very much. But there are few that do alter some stuff, nothing important at the end though. The only real important choices to take, are the last two. They define the multiple endings this game can have.The game is more about dialogue and choices than point&click action, there's not much "exploring" in it. It feels closer to watching a movie than playing the first season.**SPOILER ALERT**About the characters.Of course that everybody who played season one must love Clem.Carver is interesting to me, as it shows what Kenny would become given enough time. Jane also mentioned it.Kenny is a man hard to like, he was quite unbearable in the first season and he's not very different now. But I'm glad I didn't kill him. At the end you can see he always cared about Clem and A.J. more than himself.
